text: I feel deeply saddened and heartbroken by the horrendous terrorist attacks and events of the last week in Israel. I have written and deleted a couple of versions of what to say. I find it terribly hard to find words adequate to express my thoughts. But now its time to end my silence and maybe in a clumsy way, try to open up some discussion in a human and Psychoanalytic way that can try facilitate us as a Facebook psychoanalytic community in re finding our minds and thinking in all this horror. As a starting point and personally as the group admin i need to say that i feel the terrorist attacks that occurred in Israel this week are both horrendous, disturbing and unacceptable. My deepest sympathy go out to the people of Israel and many jewish communities around the world and in South Africa that already carry a deep intergenerational wound from the holocaust. These condolences also extend to some of my global friends and colleagues. I know that the Israel üáÆüá± conflict is complicated in its history, and not black and white. I feel the humanity of it is surely not as complicated. I think the starting point must be with an agreement that hurting, killing, torturing another person and child is inhumane. Condolences to those families and communities who are touched by this terrible conflict. Condolences to the civilians in Gaza who are now also caught in the crossfire and victims from the resulting war as a result of these terrorist attacks. (NOTE BEDATE ON THIS ABOVE SENTENCE IN COMMENTS, IT SEEMS MORE COMPLICATED) The images below can be disturbing. They are two photos from the children's room in Israel. One photo with a destroyed quarter of the city is Gaza.

While there are political, economic, cultural, and land issues at play, the basis for Israel's presence in "Israel", it's insistence in it's right to possess the land, and the unbending support for Israel by the US is founded in Jewish and Christian holy books. According to the Old Testament, the present day land known as Israel was given to God's people, the Israelis, in perpetuity. This was the "promised land" that Moses brought the Israelites to after freeing them from Egyptian slavery. The Israelites were ordered by God, according to the Bible authors, to subdue the land, conquering all of the Peoples and tribes inhabiting the land at the time. They conquered and colonized the Native peoples in 6 years and established their kingdom. The Israeli kingdom(s) were eventually conquered by others and the Israeli/Jewish people dispersed throughout the world. This changed after WWII. The Jewish people living throughout the world began to return to Israel to reclaim their promised land. They became a nation in 1948. Since then, in several wars and military actions, Israel has grown to its present shape and size... at a grave cost to the inhabitants of this land. In every case, the land was already inhabited when the Israelites arrived. (Sound familiar?) US support for Israel is also based in the Bible. It is believed, per prophecy, that when the nation of Israel is attacked by its surrounding enemies in a final battle, the Jewish Messiah will return to save his people and destroy the enemies of Israel. Christians believe the Jewish Messiah is Jesus and that "final battle" is the War Of Armageddon, ushering in the end of the world. The only two entities that will survive this "End Of Times" prophecy will be Israel, God's "natural" child and The Christian Church, God's "adopted" child. The Christian Church also has another reason for its support of "God's People", found in the Bible. Jacob, later re-named Israel, is told by God, "I will bless those who bless you and curse those who curse you." (Did I mention my belief the Bible is a book written by men, for men. It is NOT the "word of god.") Thus, the US, a "Christian" nation - is intrinsically intertwined with Israel. From pulpits in churches across the country this Sunday will be heard dire warnings of the coming end of the world and the return of Jesus who will create a new earth and a new heaven, the "New Jerusalem." Some will be praying for it to happen. If we do not wake from slumber, shake open our eyes, use critical thinking skills, and rise to resist, religion will be the death of us.

Jordan said Saturday any move by Israel to impose a new displacement of Palestinians would push the region to the "abyss" of a wider regional conflict. Foreign Minister Ayman Safadi also said Israel's blocking of humanitarian aid to Gaza and forcing its residents to leave their homes as it escalates its military action were a "flagrant" breach of international law. Israel had given the entire population of the north of the Gaza Strip a Saturday morning deadline to move south ahead of an expected ground offensive to root out Hamas militants. It has said it will keep two roads open until 4 p.m. to allow people to escape. Safadi said the military campaign against Hamas was killing innocent civilians and would bring despair and destruction in its wake that would not bring security to Israel. "The war is killing and displacing innocent Palestinians and will leave the region and the world facing the repercussion of an environment of destruction and despair that Israel will create in Gaza," Safadi said in comments after meeting his Canadian counterpart.

"MY PLATEAU EXPERIENCE IN PEACE BUILDING HELPING BROKER INDUSTRIAL HARMONY" LABOUR AND EMPLOYMENT MINISTER LALONG Minister of Labour and Employment Simon Bako Lalong says the experience he gathered in pursuing peace building and conflict management is assisting him in his current assignment as he works to bring industrial harmony which is key for the delivery of President Tinubu‚Äôs Renewed Hope Agenda. Lalong was speaking during a thanksgiving service by the Izere Nation to honour the immediate past Secretary to Plateau State Government Prof. Danladi Abok Atu held at the St. Paul's Catholic Pastoral Area, Lamingo Gwafan, Jos North Local Government. Lalong said the years of hardwork and sacrifices in building an inclusive Plateau State devoid of discrimination, oppression and injustice provided a platform for all citizens to be part of governance. He said the building of confidence and trust is essential for any government to succeed particularly where there are agitations, grievances or differences that could be exploited if not properly handled. According to him, President Bola Tinubu is desirous of developing Nigeria by ensuring that workers give their best in the public and private sectors, hence the quick attention given to the recent planned labour strike which was averted through dialogue. Lalong used the opportunity to thank the former Secretary to Plateau State Government Prof. Danladi Abok Atu whom he said worked very hard with others in implementing the Rescue Agenda of his administration. He assured the people of Plateau State that he will continue to work for the interests of the State in the Federal Government using every opportunity to attract programmes and projects not only under his area of duty but in all ways possible. Catholic Archbishop of Jos Ishaya Audu described the former Governor as a political leader with vision and passion for carrying everyone along and working with experienced persons like Prof. Danladi Abok Atu to serve the people to their best ability. While asking him to forgive anyone that may have offended him during his tenure or during political activities, Archbishop Audu appealed to Lalong to lobby and stand firm for critical issues such as roads, schools, security and other entitlements of Plateau State as a member of the Federal Executive Council. In a Homily, Msgnr Prof. Cletus Gotan said service to people is service to God and so anyone given responsibility for public office must work hard to deliver according to their mandate and with the fear of God. He said the large crowd in attendance indicates that Prof. Atu worked well with people from all walks of life who have decided to join him in thanking God. The paramount ruler of the Izere Nation Adagwom Izere Dr. Isaac Wakili said the traditional council and the Afizere Cultural and Community Development Association decided to honour Prof. Atu because he is one of its illustrious sons who has done a lot in bringing development to the Chiefdom. He said Atu also served with integrity and brought pride to the Chiefdom by not engaging in any activity that will bring shame and dishonour. In his remarks the celebrant Prof. Danladi Abok Atu thanked God for sustaining him and giving him the opportunity for public service over many years including his last assignment as Secretary to Plateau State Government under Governor Simon Lalong. Atu praised the Minister of Labour for being a man of peace, competence, compassion and integrity and for giving him the opportunity to serve as Secretary to Government. He promised to sustain the trust and asked other former appointees to also rally round the former Governor and continue to work in building strong political structures that will be useful for service. The event was attended by dignitaries from within and outside the State including Mallam Balarabe Abbas Lawal, Minister Designate and former Secretary to Kaduna State Government. The Minister of Labour and Employment later hosted some of his former appointees in his residence comprising of commissioners, Heads of Boards and Parastatals and members of the House of Assembly. Dr. Makut Simon Macham Special Adviser on Media to Hon. Minister of Labour and Employment, 15th October 2023.

Around the Web: ‚ÄúAlice Miller‚Äôs stories portray abused and silenced children who later become destructive to themselves and to others. . . . ‚ÄòThe way we were treated as small children is the way we treat ourselves the rest of our lives: with cruelty or with tenderness and protection,‚Äô [Miller says]. ‚ÄòWe often impose our most agonizing suffering upon ourselves and, later, on our children.‚Äô In 1979 Miller‚Äôs first book, The Drama of the Gifted Child, was published in Germany. First titled Prisoners of Childhood, its three short essays described how parents project their feelings, ideas, and dreams upon their children. To survive and be loved, a child learns to obey. In repressing his or her feelings, the child stifles attempts to be herself or himself. The result, said Miller, is all too often depression, ebbing of vitality, the loss of self. . . . there is hope in therapy if the therapist is a true advocate of the patient. Respect for the child within the patient and his discovery of his real history must play a role in the treatment process. The child undergoes a long inner struggle ‚Äòbetween the fear of losing the person he loves if he remains true to himself, and panic at the prospect of losing himself if he has to deny who he is. A child cannot resolve a conflict of this nature and is forced to conform because he cannot survive by himself. Therapy should not repeat this condition.‚Äô"

Six months ago, war broke out in #Sudan. Since 15 April, the conflict has claimed over 9,500 lives, while more than 5.5 million people have fled their homes because of the fighting. In August, we opened a new surgical Centre in #Khartoum to provide urgent care to those who cannot receive it in other facilities. Here we receive people burned by explosions, wounded by bullets and mines, but also patients injured in accidents or by civilian trauma. Since opening the Centre, we have treated more than 500 people. We continue cardiac surgery and cardiology at the Salam Centre even though it is becoming increasingly difficult for patients to travel. In general, it is difficult to get supplies of even essential goods, fuel and medicines; every day there is a new difficulty, in addition to deteriorating security conditions. This war attracts few headlines, but it has already triggered a massive humanitarian crisis. We will remain here. We are not abandoning Sudan.

AFFECTIONATE PERO WALANG LABEL Hello, manghihingi sana ako ng advice, pero bago yon, kuwento ko muna kung ano ang happenings. Medyo mahaba ito. There's this guy na kagrupo ko sa thesis, hindi kami close nong una, pero habang nakakasama ko siya sa paggawa ng thesis ay napapalapit ang loob ko sa kanya. Until I started to have a crush on him last month. Sa thesis group kasi namin, madalas good vibes at (humorous) asaran ang nangyayari, tapos don ako sa asaran namin na-fall. HAHA! Kapag inaasar niya ako, inaasar ko rin siya. Safe naman kasi parehas kaming walang jowa (NBSB ako and I think NGSB rin siya, base lang sa aking research. HAHAHA!). Parehas din kasi kaming introvert at taong bahay. Tapos ito, feeling ko may something din siya para sa akin, e. Kapag gumagawa kami ng manuscript, madalas niya akong tabihan at minsan sinasandalan niya rin ako. May times na nagkakasabay kami pauwi dahil kaming dalawa yong parehas ng way, at kapag umuulan ay nakiki-share siya sa kin ng payong kahit may payong din siyang dala. Kapag nagyaya akong maglakad, sumasama siya. May isang beses na nasa tricycle kami, tapos ako naman ang naglakas-loob na sumandal sa balikat niya. His response? Sinandal niya rin ang ulo niya sa ulo ko, tapos nilagay niya yong kamay niya sa tuhod ko. After that, may dalawang beses na muntik na niya akong akbayan habang naglalakad kami, kaso binabawi niya, e. Marami na rin kaming naging group overnights para sa thesis at ganon pa rin, tinatabihan niya ako at inaasar. Tapos, kapag nagbabalot ako ng kumot kasi madali akong lamigin sa aircon, nakiki-share din siya sa kumot ko habang gumagawa kami ng manuscript. May times na dinidikit niya yong binti niya sa binti ko o di kaya ay ipapatong niya ang kamay niya sa tuhod ko. Hinahayaan ko naman siya kasi comfortable naman ako na kinikilig deep inside. HAHAHA! O di ba, feeling ko mag-jowa na kami kasi ang close namin physically. But, here comes the conflict. Kapag nag-uusap kaming dalawa ay tungkol lang din sa thesis or something related. Yong asaran namin ay nangyayari lang kapag kasama namin ang groupmates namin. Once ay nagkakuwentuhan naman kaming dalawa about sa mga nababasa naming stories kasi parehas kaming reader, pero magkaiba ng medium kasi siya sa manga, ako naman sa novel. Parang yon lang ang napag-usapan namin na tungkol sa amin. Hindi ko alam kung paano ko siya kakausapin personally, at hindi rin naman siya nag-i-initiate ng ganong convo. About thesis and school stuff lang talaga ang napapag-usapan. Minsan nga, as in tahimik lang kaming magkasama pauwi. Same thing sa chats. Hindi humahaba ang convo namin, saka minsan ang tagal din kasi niyang mag-reply, tapos ang dry ng messages niya. Tapos, kapag hindi kami gumagawa ng thesis, like papasok lang sa school ganon, bihira niya akong pansinin. Napapaisip tuloy ako na baka wala naman pala talaga siyang feelings para sa kin. Naguguluhan na ako kung ano ba tong meron sa pagitan namin, or kung meron ba talaga. Tingin niyo ba, dapat ko na siyang i-confront? I really like him. Tatanggapin ko kahit anong kalalabasan ng pag-uusap namin, gusto ko lang talagang malinawan. Kaso iniisip ko, baka hindi lang talaga siya ready at matakot ko. Hindi rin ako sanay sa confrontation, baka maiyak ako, iyakin pa naman ako kapag nag-overflow na ang feelings. HAHAHA! What do you think? Too soon for a confession, or i-push ko na? INFP 20** *Confidential *** Send your stories/confessions here: www.usfstories.com

Good morning, happy Sunday and happy new week, please read with me,

OPEN HEAVENS DEVOTIONAL 

DATE: SUNDAY OCTOBER 15 2023

TOPIC: THE LAND OF ENDLESS SUFFERINGS

MEMORISE:

And shall cast them into a furnace of fire: there shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth.
Matthew 13:42

READ:
MATTHEW 13:24-30, 36-43

24 Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of heaven is likened unto a man which sowed good seed in his field:

25 But while men slept, his enemy came and sowed tares among the wheat, and went his way.

26 But when the blade was sprung up, and brought forth fruit, then appeared the tares also.

27 So the servants of the householder came and said unto him, Sir, didst not thou sow good seed in thy field? from whence then hath it tares?

28 He said unto them, An enemy hath done this. The servants said unto him, Wilt thou then that we go and gather them up?

29 But he said, Nay; lest while ye gather up the tares, ye root up also the wheat with them.

30 Let both grow together until the harvest: and in the time of harvest I will say to the reapers, Gather ye together first the tares, and bind them in bundles to burn them: but gather the wheat into my barn.

36 Then Jesus sent the multitude away, and went into the house: and his disciples came unto him, saying, Declare unto us the parable of the tares of the field.

37 He answered and said unto them, He that soweth the good seed is the Son of man;

38 The field is the world; the good seed are the children of the kingdom; but the tares are the children of the wicked one;

39 The enemy that sowed them is the devil; the harvest is the end of the world; and the reapers are the angels.

40 As therefore the tares are gathered and burned in the fire; so shall it be in the end of this world.

41 The Son of man shall send forth his angels, and they shall gather out of his kingdom all things that offend, and them which do iniquity;

42 And shall cast them into a furnace of fire: there shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth.

43 Then shall the righteous shine forth as the sun in the kingdom of their Father. Who hath ears to hear, let him hear.

MESSAGE:

Those who don't end up in the City of God will end up in another place that I cannot describe as a city. I can only describe it as a place of endless sufferings because it is a land of unimaginable horrors. All the residents of this horrific place are in constant suffering for eternity. That place is called hell fire (Mark 9:47). The first thing you need to know about hell fire is that it is a place of torment. Luke 16:23 describes the experience of a man in hell as follows: "And in hell he lift up his eyes, being in torments, and seeth Abraham afar off, and Lazarus in his bosom." 

All occupants of hell are tormented non-stop. In Mark 9:48, Jesus tells us some of the things that torment them: "Where their worm dieth not, and the fire is not quenched."

The passage does not say 'the worm' does not die, but 'their worm'. In other words, worms will be coming out of the body of the people there, and these worms cannot be killed. They just keep eating their victims up. Also, there is an unquenchable fire there that keeps burning the occupants of hell non-stop. In Matthew 25:41, Jesus said the fire is everlasting. Revelations 14:11 says the smoke of their torment in hell goes up forever and that there is no rest day or night; the torment just goes on without stopping for eternity. A drop of water will be a luxury to the people in hell (Luke 16:24). Can you imagine such torment? There is no nightmare that can compare to the actual experience of hell fire.

There are many passages in the Bible where Jesus described hell as a place where there will be a lot of weeping, wailing and gnashing of teeth. Even assuming that the torments are the cause of their wailing, what then would make them gnash their teeth? Gnashing of teeth is something people do when they regret their actions or inactions. The people in hell will be gnashing their teeth for eternity, regretting that they did not live holy lives when they were on earth. You are still here on earth, so you have the opportunity that those people will give anything to have again. You have the opportunity to repent and start living holy now. If you delay until it is too late, you would remember this message in hell and wish you had listened. Choose wisely.

REFLECTION:

Think about it carefully: are you willing to go to hell becasuse of that sin you keep committing? If not, stop it today.

BIBLE IN ONE YEAR:
MARK 6-7

World Food Day, 16th October ‚ÄúWater is life, water is food. Leave no one behind‚Äù. At the Sir Brian Bell Foundation, we proudly support World Food Day and the 2023 theme ‚ÄúWater is life, water is food. Leave no one behind‚Äù. Water is one of the planet's most precious resources, it must be protected and preserved so everyone has access to clean and safe water solutions. What we eat and how we prepare our food all affect the water in our community. As individuals we all have a part to play in ensuring we improve the way we use water in our daily lives for future generations. Bronwyn Wright, CEO of the Sir Brian Bell Foundation commented ‚ÄúAs a nation we have progressed to consuming more packaged and fast foods out of convenience, which often has negative impacts on our health and our environment. Healthy habits make for healthy bodies and healthy minds so, try and fill your plate with local PNG produce and wash it down with fresh and clean water. The more natural and unprocessed the better it will be for you. We‚Äôre lucky to have so much local food to choose from in our beautiful country. At the end of the day, you are what you eat!‚Äù commented Sir Brian Bell Foundation, CEO, Ms Bronwyn Wright. Let‚Äôs all work together for a more nourished nation, take action and reduce water waste for our future generations. United Nations: Water is essential to life on Earth. It makes up over 50% of our bodies and covers about 71% of the Earth's surface. Only 2.5% of water is fresh, suitable for drinking, agriculture, and most industrial uses. Water is a driving force for people, economies and nature and the foundation of our food. Indeed, agriculture accounts for 72% of global freshwater withdrawals, but like all natural resources, fresh water is not infinite. Rapid population growth, urbanization, economic development, and climate change are putting the planet‚Äôs water resources under increasing stress. At the same time, freshwater resources per person have declined by 20% in the past decades and water availability and quality are deteriorating fast due to decades of poor use and management, over-extraction of groundwater, pollution, and climate change. We risk stretching this precious resource to a point of no return. Today, 2.4 billion people live in water-stressed countries. Many are smallholder farmers who already struggle to meet their daily needs, particularly women, Indigenous Peoples, migrants, and refugees. Competition for this priceless resource is increasing as water scarcity becomes an ever-increasing cause of conflict. Around 600 million people who depend, at least partially, on aquatic food systems for a living are suffering the effects of pollution, ecosystem degradation, unsustainable practices, and climate change. It‚Äôs time to start managing water wisely. We need to produce more food and other essential agricultural commodities with less water while ensuring water is distributed equally, our aquatic food systems are preserved, and nobody is left behind. Governments need to design science and evidence-based policies that capitalize on data, innovation, and cross-sectoral coordination to better plan and manage water. They need to support these policies with increased investment, legislation, technologies, and capacity development while incentivizing farmers and the private sector to engage in integrated solutions for a more efficient use of water, and for its conservation. We all need to stop taking water for granted and start improving the way we use it in our daily lives. What we eat, and how that food is produced all affect water. We can make a difference by choosing local, seasonal, and fresh foods, wasting less of it - even by reducing food waste, and finding safe ways to reuse it while preventing water pollution. Together, we can take water action for the future of food, people, and the planet. Learn More: https://www.fao.org/world-food-day/en #worldfoodday

Ballykissangel is a BBC television drama created by Kieran Prendiville and set in Ireland, produced in-house by BBC Northern Ireland. The original story revolved around a young English Roman Catholic priest as he became part of a rural community. It ran for six series, which were first broadcast on BBC One in the United Kingdom from 1996 to 2001. It aired in Ireland on RT√â One and in Australia on ABC TV from 1996 to 2001. Repeats have been shown on Drama in the United Kingdom and in the United States on some PBS affiliates. The series was made and set during the Celtic Tiger economic period in Ireland and this features mainly through Tony Doyle‚Äôs character, Brian Quigley. The show is also set amid the backdrop of the Catholic Church scandal and explores controversial themes of the time such as divorce (which had only been legalised a year before the series began), and pre-marital sex. Dervla Kirwan‚Äôs and Niall Toibin‚Äôs characters are often at odds, symbolising the social conflict between traditional Ireland and social liberalisation. Significant changes in the cast occurred at the end of series 3 following the departure of central characters Peter Clifford and Assumpta Fitzgerald. A band of new characters were brought in and characters that previously had little story were expanded, such as Kathleen, Niamh, Frank and Brian. The show faced a decline in ratings from a peak level of 10 million viewers to 4.8 million and was eventually cancelled in 2001. The name of the fictional village in which the show was set is derived from Ballykissane, a townland near Killorglin in County Kerry, where the show's creator, Kieran Prendiville, holidayed with his family as a child. The village's name in Irish is shown as "Baile Coisc Aingeal", which means "The town of the fallen angel", on the sign outside the post office.[4] The show was filmed in Avoca and Enniskerry in County Wicklow.

Life feels heavy right now. It‚Äôs good and there‚Äôs so much I‚Äôm thankful for and I don‚Äôt let the darkness outweigh the light of good shining on me but I‚Äôm honest. Life‚Äôs hard. Health scares and unknowns, broken relationships and unsolved issues. Conflict and confusion and feels like no matter the option the outcome is going to still suck. Because sometimes things just suck. And I‚Äôve let myself get lost in the suck today. I hate that. I kept busy but my mind raced more than the activities I did. Listened to music, which normally calms me but today I just heard sadness. Tried reading but after reading the same paragraph over and over I gave up. I took P to the store because I love to buy half the grocery and bring home nothing of nutritional value but he loves going with. We walked in and he went to get the buggy and then stopped to let an older lady pass, he smiled and gave her the ‚Äúgo ahead‚Äù with his hand and she was beaming and smiled at us both. A guy passed us and P gave him the universal man nod, like ‚Äúwassup‚Äù and the guy did it back and smiled then looked at me and winked. P brings joy to others by just being. He scanned all the groceries, used my card to pay then grabbed the bags, ‚Äúhere mom, let me‚Ä¶‚Äù We walked outside and it was gloomy and cold and he was struggling to carry the bags but I looked at him and my heart was just full. If you were to list the things he doesn‚Äôt have, the people who have disappointed him, the things that should leave a mark on him, there‚Äôd be too many for his young heart to process. You wouldn‚Äôt know it by looking at him. He loves his people big. He looks for ways to include others. He goes out of his way to help. He sings to himself day and night because he has music in his heart that speaks louder than anything negative around him. We got in the car and I looked in the rear view mirror as he was digging into the Oreos and as I was about to tell him how proud of him I was he said something that made me cry. ‚ÄúMama, I‚Äôm sad. I should have made that lady‚Äôs day.‚Äù I asked what he was talking about and he said he should have given that lady his buggy instead of just moving it to let her pass. I told him that he has a huge heart and that‚Äôs a great idea for next time but I bet that that lady‚Äôs day was made because a really handsome, sweet and kind person saw her, acknowledged her and smiled her way. He looked at me and smiled, with Oreos all in his teeth and said, ‚Äúyea, true!‚Äù We overcomplicate things. We concentrate too much on what we didn‚Äôt do instead of acknowledging what we did. What we have done well and right and good. Not everyone we passed greeted P with the same smile and excitement as he was giving but it didn‚Äôt stop him from giving it to the next person. There‚Äôs a lot on my heart and Satan likes to use these moments to remind me of all I‚Äôm lacking, all I‚Äôm missing and how much doesn‚Äôt make sense. My son was a gentle reminder today that it doesn‚Äôt take much to make a beautiful day and if the one person doesn‚Äôt smile back at you, smile again at the next one. Sometimes in the middle of a perfectly annoying day where everything gets on your nerves, you‚Äôre reminded of how beautiful the simple is by the brightest of lights. üíóüíó Just a Girl, With a lot to say

AFFECTIONATE PERO WALANG LABEL Hello, manghihingi sana ako ng advice, pero bago yon, kuwento ko muna kung ano ang happenings. Medyo mahaba ito. There's this guy na kagrupo ko sa thesis, hindi kami close nong una, pero habang nakakasama ko siya sa paggawa ng thesis ay napapalapit ang loob ko sa kanya. Until I started to have a crush on him last month. Sa thesis group kasi namin, madalas good vibes at (humorous) asaran ang nangyayari, tapos don ako sa asaran namin na-fall. HAHA! Kapag inaasar niya ako, inaasar ko rin siya. Safe naman kasi parehas kaming walang jowa (NBSB ako and I think NGSB rin siya, base lang sa aking research. HAHAHA!). Parehas din kasi kaming introvert at taong bahay. Tapos ito, feeling ko may something din siya para sa akin, e. Kapag gumagawa kami ng manuscript, madalas niya akong tabihan at minsan sinasandalan niya rin ako. May times na nagkakasabay kami pauwi dahil kaming dalawa yong parehas ng way, at kapag umuulan ay nakiki-share siya sa kin ng payong kahit may payong din siyang dala. Kapag nagyaya akong maglakad, sumasama siya. May isang beses na nasa tricycle kami, tapos ako naman ang naglakas-loob na sumandal sa balikat niya. His response? Sinandal niya rin ang ulo niya sa ulo ko, tapos nilagay niya yong kamay niya sa tuhod ko. After that, may dalawang beses na muntik na niya akong akbayan habang naglalakad kami, kaso binabawi niya, e. Marami na rin kaming naging group overnights para sa thesis at ganon pa rin, tinatabihan niya ako at inaasar. Tapos, kapag nagbabalot ako ng kumot kasi madali akong lamigin sa aircon, nakiki-share din siya sa kumot ko habang gumagawa kami ng manuscript. May times na dinidikit niya yong binti niya sa binti ko o di kaya ay ipapatong niya ang kamay niya sa tuhod ko. Hinahayaan ko naman siya kasi comfortable naman ako na kinikilig deep inside. HAHAHA! O di ba, feeling ko mag-jowa na kami kasi ang close namin physically. But, here comes the conflict. Kapag nag-uusap kaming dalawa ay tungkol lang din sa thesis or something related. Yong asaran namin ay nangyayari lang kapag kasama namin ang groupmates namin. Once ay nagkakuwentuhan naman kaming dalawa about sa mga nababasa naming stories kasi parehas kaming reader, pero magkaiba ng medium kasi siya sa manga, ako naman sa novel. Parang yon lang ang napag-usapan namin na tungkol sa amin. Hindi ko alam kung paano ko siya kakausapin personally, at hindi rin naman siya nag-i-initiate ng ganong convo. About thesis and school stuff lang talaga ang napapag-usapan. Minsan nga, as in tahimik lang kaming magkasama pauwi. Same thing sa chats. Hindi humahaba ang convo namin, saka minsan ang tagal din kasi niyang mag-reply, tapos ang dry ng messages niya. Tapos, kapag hindi kami gumagawa ng thesis, like papasok lang sa school ganon, bihira niya akong pansinin. Napapaisip tuloy ako na baka wala naman pala talaga siyang feelings para sa kin. Naguguluhan na ako kung ano ba tong meron sa pagitan namin, or kung meron ba talaga. Tingin niyo ba, dapat ko na siyang i-confront? I really like him. Tatanggapin ko kahit anong kalalabasan ng pag-uusap namin, gusto ko lang talagang malinawan. Kaso iniisip ko, baka hindi lang talaga siya ready at matakot ko. Hindi rin ako sanay sa confrontation, baka maiyak ako, iyakin pa naman ako kapag nag-overflow na ang feelings. HAHAHA! What do you think? Too soon for a confession, or i-push ko na? INFP 20** *Confidential *** Send your stories/confessions here: www.usfstories.com

On this date in 1970, CANNED HEAT debuted at No. 84 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart with their single LET'S WORK TOGETHER (Oct 10, 1970)

NOTE: The video here is CANNED HEAT performing LET'S WORK TOGETHER on the German TV show 'Beat Club' in 1970. I've upscaled and improved the colour saturation of the original film.

A blues-based rhythm and blues number that made a plea for fidelity in a fractured marriage, 'Let's Stick Together' was written by Wilbert Harrison and released in 1962, Harrison further developed the song and in 1969 when issued it was issued as a two-part single titled "Let's Work Together".

Changing the title to "Let's Work Together," Harrison's new message of unity was aimed at a nation rife with conflict over the Civil Rights Movement and the Vietnam War. 

Shortly after the release of Wilbert Harrison's "Let's Work Together", L.A. blues-rock band Canned Heat recorded their version of the song. 

Unlike their previous singles ("On the Road Again", "Going Up the Country", and "Time Was") that featured vocals and harmonica by Alan Wilson, for "Let's Work Together" Bob Hite provided the vocals, with Wilson adding the slide-guitar parts.

The song was prepared for release as a single in December 1969, but was cancelled due to the popularity of Harrison's single.

In the UK, where Harrison's single failed to generate interest, Canned Heat's version was released in January 1970.

There it became their biggest hit, reaching number two on the UK Singles chart during a stay of fifteen weeks.

Several artists subsequently recorded the songs: "Let's Work Together" by Canned Heat (1970) and "Let's Stick Together" by Bryan Ferry (1976) were both chart successes.

Canned Heat didn't mean to overshadow Harrison with their version. In fact, if they'd known the singer was going to have success with it, they never would have recorded it in the first place. 

They first heard the tune when it was still making the rounds at underground radio stations. Their new guitarist Harvey Mandel played it for the rest of the guys and suggested they cover it, but their co-vocalist, Bob "The Bear" Hite, wanted to wait a few months to see if Harrison would chart first. 

According to drummer Adolfo de la Parra, Hite didn't like taking songs away from living black musicians unless they weren't hits.

"If the song languished among blues collectors, then he thought we could carry it to a bigger audience and at least get the composer writer's royalties," de la Parra wrote in his book, Living The Blues. 

They recorded the tune in December 1969 without knowing Harrison would get a chart entry just a couple months later.

"It was the perfect vehicle for Bob, summoning the world to get together and make someone happy," de la Parra explained.

It was his greatest performance and only hit. The song also enhanced Canned Heat's dual character, a band with two lead singers with very different styles and voices."

A Prayer for Peace

Lord Jesus Christ,
You are the true King of peace.
In You alone is found freedom.

Please free our world from conflict.
Bring unity to troubled nations.
Let Your glorious peace reign in every heart.

Dispel all darkness and evil.
Protect the dignity of every human life.
Replace hatred with Your love.

Give wisdom to world leaders.
Free them from selfish ambition.
Eliminate all violence and war.

Glorious Virgin Mary,
Saint Michael the Archangel,
Every angel and saint:
Please pray for peace.
Pray for unity amongst nations.
Pray for unity amongst all people.
Pray for the most vulnerable.
Pray for those suffering.
Pray for the fearful.
Pray for those most in need.
Pray for us all.

Jesus, Son of the Living God, have mercy on us.
Jesus, hear our prayers.
Jesus, I trust in You!

Amen.

Prayer for Peace‚ÄîSt. John Paul II

Salah ad-Din Yusuf ibn Ayyub (1137 ‚Äì 4 March 1193) Commonly known as Saladin (Honour of the Faith) or the King Who Grants Victory, Sultan of Egypt and Syria, and Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques. Was the founder of the Ayyubid dynasty. Hailing from a Kurdish family, he was the first Sultan of both Egypt and Syria. At the height of his power, the Ayyubid realm spanned Egypt, Syria, Upper Mesopotamia, the Hejaz, Yemen, and Nubia. Although the Ayyubid dynasty that he founded would outlive him by only 57 years, the legacy of Saladin within the Arab World continues to this day. With the rise of Arab nationalism in the 20th Century, particularly with regard to the Arab‚ÄìIsraeli conflict, Saladin's heroism and leadership gained a new significance. Saladin's recapture of Palestine from the European Crusaders is considered an inspiration for modern-day Arabs' opposition to Zionism. Saladin was widely renowned in medieval Europe as a model of kingship, and in particular of the courtly virtue of regal generosity. In The Divine Comedy (1308‚Äì1320), Dante mentiones him as one of the virtuous non-Christians. In 1171, he abolished the Cairo-based Shia Muslim Caliphate and realigned Egypt with the Baghdad-based Sunni Abbasid Caliphate. In the following years, he led forays against the Crusaders in Palestine, and commissioned the successful conquest of Yemen. Crusader attacks provoked further responses by Saladin. Raynald of Ch√¢tillon, in particular, harassed Muslim trading and pilgrimage routes with a fleet on the Red Sea, a water route that Saladin needed to keep open. Raynald threatened to attack the holy cities of Mecca and Medina. On 4 July 1187, Saladin faced the combined forces of Guy of Lusignan, King Consort of Jerusalem, and Raymond III of Tripoli at the Battle of Hattin. In this battle alone the Crusader force was largely annihilated by Saladin's determined army. It was a major disaster for the Crusaders and a turning point in the history of the Crusades. Saladin captured Raynald and was personally responsible for his execution in retaliation for his attacks against Muslim caravans. The members of these caravans had, in vain, besought his mercy by reciting the truce between the Muslims and the Crusaders, but Raynald ignored this and insulted the Islamic prophet, Muhammad, before murdering and torturing some of them. Upon hearing this, Saladin swore an oath to personally execute Raynald. Guy of Lusignan was also captured. Seeing the execution of Raynald, he feared he would be next. However, his life was spared by Saladin, who said of Raynald, "it is not the wont of kings, to kill kings; but that man had transgressed all bounds, and therefore did I treat him thus." Capture of Jerusalem Saladin had captured almost every Crusader city. Saladin preferred to take Jerusalem without bloodshed and offered generous terms, but those inside refused to leave their holy city, vowing to destroy it in a fight to the death rather than see it handed over peacefully. Jerusalem capitulated to his forces on Friday, 2 October 1187, after a siege. When the siege had started, Saladin was unwilling to promise terms of quarter to the Frankish inhabitants of Jerusalem. Balian of Ibelin threatened to kill every Muslim hostage, estimated at 5,000, and to destroy Islam's holy shrines of the Dome of the Rock and the al-Aqsa Mosque if such quarter were not provided. Saladin consulted his council and the terms were accepted. The agreement was read out through the streets of Jerusalem so that everyone might within forty days provide for himself and pay to Saladin the agreed tribute for his freedom. An unusually low ransom was to be paid for each Frank in the city, whether man, woman, or child, but Saladin, against the wishes of his treasurers, allowed many families who could not afford the ransom to leave. Upon the capture of Jerusalem, Saladin summoned the Jews and permitted them to resettle in the city. Saladin died of a fever on 4 March 1193 (27 Safar 589 AH) at Damascus, not long after King Richard's departure. In Saladin's possession at the time of his death were one piece of gold and forty pieces of silver. He had given away his great wealth to his poor subjects, leaving nothing to pay for his funeral. He was buried in a mausoleum in the garden outside the Umayyad Mosque in Damascus, Syria. Seven centuries later, Emperor Wilhelm II of Germany donated a new marble sarcophagus to the mausoleum. However, the original sarcophagus was not replaced. 20th-century French author Albert Champdor described him as "Le plus pur h√©ros de l'Islam" (English: The purest Hero of Islam). Despite the Crusaders' slaughter when they originally conquered Jerusalem in 1099, Saladin granted amnesty and free passage to all common Catholics and even to the defeated Christian army (the Greek Orthodox Christians were treated even better because they often opposed the western Crusaders). Conflict can actually create deeper connections between people - but only if managed constructively. 
‚Äå
Conflict happens when people have differing opinions, needs, or desires, and how it's approached and resolved can impact relationships.
‚Äå
Avoiding conflict by suppressing your feelings, avoiding difficult conversations, or pleasing others can lead to surface-level relationships where true thoughts and emotions are not expressed. This avoidance may create a fa√ßade of harmony but can hinder authentic connections.
‚Äå
On the other hand, when you engage in conflicts openly and respectfully, you have the opportunity to express your viewpoints, understand each other's perspectives, and work through differences.
‚Äå
Here‚Äôs three ways you can do this:
‚Äå
‚ñ´Ô∏èSeek Compromise: Instead of aiming for a win-lose outcome, strive for a win-win solution. Look for common ground and compromise where possible.
‚Äå
‚ñ´Ô∏èAwareness of Emotions: Before engaging in a conflict, it‚Äôs essential to be aware of your own emotions. Understand what you‚Äôre feeling and why.
‚Äå
‚ñ´Ô∏èUse ‚ÄúI‚Äù Statements: Express your feelings and concerns using ‚ÄúI‚Äù statements, such as ‚ÄúI feel hurt when‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm concerned about‚Ä¶‚Äù This approach focuses on your own emotions and experiences rather than making accusatory ‚Äúyou‚Äù statements, which can escalate the conflict.
‚Äå
Approaching conflict with empathy, effective communication, and a willingness to find common ground can help turn conflicts into opportunities for growth and connection.
‚Äå
Follow for more content on emotional growth and tips on healthy relationships: @well.guide

(Note: this does not apply to abusive relationships)

MSNBC has quietly taken 3 of its Muslim broadcasters, with some of the deepest knowledge of the conflict, out of the anchor‚Äôs chair since the war began last Saturday. Ayman covered the conflict from Gaza for two years as the only English language reporter in the strip. 

The moves come as MSNBC ‚Äî like the Democratic Party with which it‚Äôs often aligned ‚Äî has swung into intense solidarity with the Jewish state after the murderous Hamas attacks. That shift has come with heated internal and external objections to anything that breaks with that solidarity, and has come with social media criticism of Hasan, Mohyeldin, and Velshi. Hasan has also been vocal on X, formerly known as Twitter, condemning the Hamas attack and calling attention to the plight of civilians in Gaza.

In 2014, Mohyeldin, the network‚Äôs most experienced reporter in Gaza, was abruptly pulled from NBC‚Äôs coverage of the region and replaced by Richard Engel for several days. CNN reported at the time that NBC executives did not give him a concrete explanation beyond citing vague ‚Äúsecurity reasons.‚Äù Semafor reported that when violence erupted in Gaza in 2021, MSNBC executives had privately expressed discomfort with hosts Hasan and Mohyeldin for their coverage.

Conservative media has put pressure on MSNBC to shift further toward Israel in its coverage.

The criticism of the three MSNBC hosts ‚Äî three of the most high-profile Muslim on-air personalities on the network‚Äî seems vastly disproportionate to anything they‚Äôve said on air. 

NBC did not release a statement about why it pulled Mohyeldin in 2014. And when I wrote an article about Hasan and Mohyeldin‚Äôs coverage of the flare-up in 2021, MSNBC did not make either host available for comment. MSNBC appears to be avoiding any suggestion that it could be aligned with a view that‚Äôs more centered on Palestinian civilians, and trying to protect itself and its Muslim stars by putting them in the roles of correspondents and analysts, not at the center of its programming. ‚Äî Max Tani for Semafor

*Moshe Arenstein, a former intelligence officer in the Israeli military, is a senior executive producer at MSNBC*

Regardless of one's religious or cultural background, it is imperative as humans that we cannot turn a blind eye to the dire situation unfolding in Palestine. We cannot, and must not, stay silent; we must talk about it openly. This is not a 'complicated conflict,' nor is it a situation that necessitates excessive nuance. It's not a 'geopolitical event' that requires us to make vague condemnations of 'bad actors' on 'both sides.'

What we are witnessing is nothing short of a genocide. The Israeli state's actions against the Palestinian people are unequivocally a genocide, and it is occurring right before our eyes. There is no room for ambiguity; it is a genocide, carried out by the Israeli state against the Palestinian population. You don't need to read between the lines: Israel has openly, with little resistance from so-called liberal democracies, severed Gaza's access to essential resources such as water, food, and electricity. This has left more than two million Palestinians, including a million children, deprived of even the most basic necessities for life.

Consider this staggering fact: in just six days, Israel has dropped 6,000 bombs on the besieged coastal enclave, home to 2.3 million Palestinians, half of whom are innocent children. Israel's use of internationally banned white phosphorus, the heartbreaking deaths of babies as young as seven days old, and their orders for 1.1 million people to evacuate their homes within 24 hours, followed by bombings that injure and kill those attempting to flee, are all reprehensible acts.

What we are witnessing is nothing less than ethnic cleansing in full view of the world. We cannot, in good conscience, look away from these unspeakable horrors. It is our moral duty to discuss this crisis openly and take decisive action to bring it to an end. Humanity demands nothing less.

Furthermore, it is crucial to be aware that Instagram is actively restricting accounts that post about the situation in Palestine. Therefore, we urge you to share and talk about it as much as possible to ensure that the truth is not silenced.

These are some words that have and are keeping me afloat right now. All of us are chosen. No more taking turns on history‚Äôs wheel. 
.
Eclipses obscure light, metaphorically forcing us to find it within. To foster it. To refuse to let it be extinguished no matter what it is we face. 
.
Life is light. Life is the most sacred thing, the only thing to defend. Not power. Not borders. I dream of states of abundance and shared resources (like friendship). I dream of children being taught how to honor conflict and create peace. I dream of people migrating because they can, not fleeing because they have to. 
.
I am grieving the loss of life, hope, and any kind of progress that Israeli, Palestinian and international peace activists have made over the past many decades. 
.
This was the first of a series of eclipses in Libra near the south node - a point of emptying and release. It feels more like a tear through the fabric of our universe and I wonder how we could ever come back from it - or build forward from it. It feels impossible - but it is not. As Libra and the poets teach us, the way makes itself known when we go together. Only together. 
.

Attachment theory is so much more than knowing your attachment style‚Ä¶.it‚Äôs a theory about learning to connect and using the power of connection as a way for partners to reach each other‚Ä¶.secure attachment is about maximizing connection and every interaction between partners, even the smallest, provides an opportunity for connection. Insecure attachment represents a lack of connection to self the difficulty connecting to your partner. What is connection? Connection is a feeling of closeness and safety, a sharing of selves. Even during conflict, partners can learn to maintain connection. Even when your partner is acting out of fear, you can still do your part to maintain connection. Even when you are acting out of fear, your partner can still do their part to maintain connection. How do you connect? Listening, validation, empathy, understanding, co-regulation, setting healthy boundaries, communicating your wants and needs with connection in mind, and respond to your partner‚Äôs wants and needs with connection in mind. 
My account is dedicated to teaching all the different ways to do all of these things. ü™¥

A 6-year-old boy is dead, and his mother seriously wounded after they were both stabbed more than a dozen times due to their Muslim faith Saturday in a Chicago suburb.

Around 11:38 a.m., deputies with the Will County Sheriff's Office responded to a home located near the intersection of S. Lincoln Highway and Lily Cache Road in Plainfield for a report of a stabbing.

A 32-year-old woman had called 9-1-1 and stated her landlord had attacked her with a knife, and that she ran into the bathroom and continued to fight off her attacker as she dialed 9-1-1.

When officers arrived at the scene, they located the suspect ‚Äì identified as 71-year-old Joseph M. Czuba ‚Äì sitting on the ground outside the home with a laceration to his forehead. He was transported to an area hospital for treatment.

Inside the home, in a bedroom, police say they located two victims who had multiple stab wounds to their chest, torso, and upper extremities. The 32-year-old woman was hospitalized in serious condition with over a dozen stab wounds to her body. A 6-year-old boy had also suffered 26 stab wounds throughout his body and was pronounced dead at the hospital.

The knife used in the attack was seven inches long and serrated.

Czuba was treated and released from the hospital, and taken by police for questioning. He was charged with first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, two counts of hate crime and aggravated battery with a deadly weapon.

"Detectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis," according to the Will County Sheriff's Office.

The weapon used in this "heinous crime" was recovered, police said.

The investigation is ongoing.üëÄ

Most Americans believe the U.S. government should publicly express support for Israel in its war against the Palestinian militant group Hamas, a new poll found.‚Å†
‚Å†
The NPR-PBS News Hour-Marist poll found that nearly two in three Americans ‚Äî or roughly 65 percent ‚Äî say the government should publicly support Israel. About 23 percent said the U.S. should say or do nothing related to the conflict, and 8 percent say the U.S. should publicly criticize Israel.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚Å†
Partisanship did not seem to play much of a role in the results, either, according to the poll. Around 77 percent of Republicans, 69 percent of Democrats and 54 percent of independents said they believe the U.S. should show public support for Israel amid the war.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúIsrael is clearly winning in the court of public opinion,‚Äù Lee M. Miringoff, director of Maris College Institute for Public Opinion said in a statement.‚Å†

More than half of Americans also think U.S. support for Israel makes the Middle East safer. Kauthar Bouchallikht heeft zich teruggetrokken van de kandidatenlijst van GroenLinks/PvdA voor de verkiezingen van komende maand. Ze vindt dat haar partij GroenLinks de afgelopen week te weinig aandacht heeft geschonken aan de context van het Palestijns-Isra√´lische conflict, schrijft ze in een bericht op Instagram. "Dit is niet meer de partij waar ik Kamerlid voor wil zijn."

"Deze 'oorlog' is niet plots begonnen, hij is al 75 jaar bezig", schrijft ze. "Juist nu is het moment voor context. Context is namelijk geen ontkenning van de afschuwelijke daden door Hamas afgelopen weekend. Context is het erkennen waar die vandaan komen, namelijk het handelen van de Isra√´lische regering, ook tegen de zin van vele Isra√´li√´rs en joodse mensen in."

GroenLinks-fractievoorzitter Klaver schrijft in een reactie dat het besluit van Bouchallikht hem verrast en verdrietig stemt. "Ik heb het een voorrecht gevonden om met je samen te werken de afgelopen jaren. Dit is jouw besluit en dat respecteer ik. Je bent een voorbeeld voor velen en dat blijf je", aldus Klaver.

Today, as I reflect on the ongoing conflict between Israel & Palestine, my heart is heavy, not as a Canadian Muslim but as a human being who has always believed in the power of reconciliation & unity.

When someone declares, "I stand with Israel" on social media, it is essential to understand the depth & nuances of such a statement. This should not mean a blank cheque of support for the loss of tens of thousands of innocent lives‚Äîchildren, women, & the elderly in Gaza or Palestine. Similarly, to say, "I stand with Palestine" should not be an endorsement of the actions of extremist factions, Hamas or the harm inflicted upon innocent Jewish lives & people.

But herein lies the challenge in choosing a side, we must always be guided by an informed conscience & a deep understanding of history. Because, in the grand arc of time, it's not about picking popular side or looking cool, but ensuring we find ourselves on the right side of history.

Both the Israeli & Palestinian governments have made choices that are deeply regrettable. Actions that have resulted in loss, pain, death & suffering. Both sides have blemishes in their histories. However, the errors of governments should never be seen as the errors of their people. We cannot allow the mistakes of a few corrupt politicians & extremist to justify the suffering of the many, whether it's through violence, deprivation of basic necessities like electricity, water, & food, or the profound pain of lost loved ones.

At the core of this conflict are two groups of people with more in common than they might realize. Muslims & Jews share profound theological, cultural, & historical ties. We are in many ways, brothers & sisters under the vast canopy of Abrahamic faiths. To see them in conflict is a tragic irony of history.

So, what then is our role? It is a call & demand for peace, understanding, & most importantly, action. We must move past divisive narratives & work towards building bridges. Our focus should be on the innocent lives caught in the crossfire & the future generations who deserve a world of peace & prosperity. Let's make a collective plea for sanity, for love, for understanding. Let us stand united agains

McDonald's Turkey has taken a significant step towards alleviating the humanitarian crisis in Gaza by announcing a generous donation of $1 million.

Their donation is aimed at providing essential support to those affected by the conflict, with special attention to women, children, and the elderly.

This initiative stems from a recent controversy surrounding "McDonald's Israel," which was reported to be distributing free meals to the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF). ¬†This revelation sparked a strong reaction in Turkey, prompting calls for a boycott of the fast-food giant within the country.

In response to these developments, McDonald's Turkey issued an official statement to clarify its position. They emphasized their status as a locally-owned business and stressed that there was no operational or organizational connection between McDonald's Turkey and McDonald's Israel.

According to their statement, McDonald's Israel operates independently and is solely responsible for its business and communication decisions.

A 6-year-old boy is dead, and his mother seriously wounded after they were both stabbed more than a dozen times due to their Muslim faith Saturday in a Chicago suburb.

Around 11:38 a.m., deputies with the Will County Sheriff's Office responded to a home located near the intersection of S. Lincoln Highway and Lily Cache Road in Plainfield for a report of a stabbing.

A 32-year-old woman had called 9-1-1 and stated her landlord had attacked her with a knife, and that she ran into the bathroom and continued to fight off her attacker as she dialed 9-1-1.

When officers arrived at the scene, they located the suspect ‚Äì identified as 71-year-old Joseph M. Czuba ‚Äì sitting on the ground outside the home with a laceration to his forehead. He was transported to an area hospital for treatment.

Inside the home, in a bedroom, police say they located two victims who had multiple stab wounds to their chest, torso, and upper extremities. The 32-year-old woman was hospitalized in serious condition with over a dozen stab wounds to her body. A 6-year-old boy had also suffered 26 stab wounds throughout his body and was pronounced dead at the hospital.

The knife used in the attack was seven inches long and serrated.

Czuba was treated and released from the hospital, and taken by police for questioning. He was charged with first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, two counts of hate crime and aggravated battery with a deadly weapon.

"Detectives were able to determine that both victims in this brutal attack were targeted by the suspect due to them being Muslim and the on-going Middle Eastern conflict involving Hamas and the Israelis," according to the Will County Sheriff's Office.

The weapon used in this "heinous crime" was recovered, police said.

The investigation is ongoing.üëÄ

Additionally, US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin disclosed that the warships are a representation of the US commitment to maintaining Israel's security rather than being involved in Israel's operations or the combat in Gaza.

The deployments highlight the US goal of deterring any actions, whether from states or non-state actors, that could further escalate the conflict.

My heart bleeds as a fellow human who fled my homeland due to the horrors of civil war in Lebanon.
As a Lebanese born Canadian, I and my family still carry the weight of that experience, understanding the paralyzing fear, heart-wrenching uncertainty, and trauma that lingers. It's a haunting reminder of the nightmares that conflict can unleash.

Having lived through that dark chapter, I find it especially terrifying to see history repeating itself, to see innocent children, families, and communities being subjected to aggression and killing. I understand intimately the generational impact of such violence, and it fills me with a deep sense of urgency to advocate for peace for all innocent Palestinian and Israeli civilians.

My heart is with all the innocent victims in this conflict. Period. There's an urgent deep concern as we bear witness to the unfolding humanitarian crisis in Gaza.
I pray for the strength of those who continue to endure and my heart reaches out to all who struggle during this unprecedented time.

In my role as a musician, my nature is to unite people of all walks of life, spread happiness and positivity. It's a service and opportunity that I am immensely proud of and keep close to my heart. 

I, as many of you during these difficult times, find it a struggle; being torn between the desire to uplift and bring joy to others through music, and the overwhelming sorrow and grief in my heart from all we are bearing witness to.

Five days into the bloody situation in Israel and Gaza, the Indian government‚Äôs only response was one tweet from Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Put out on October 7, it has over 27 million views and was lacking in nuance ‚Äì describing the attacks by Hamas as ‚Äúterrorist attacks‚Äù, and expressing solidarity with Israel. The Foreign Ministry and External Affairs Minister (EAM) S. Jaishanker had simply retweeted the prime minister‚Äôs tweet and left it at that.

Now, six days into the conflict, we have finally heard from the EAM spokesperson. But yet again, there is no direct re-assertion of India‚Äôs support for the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people. The statement makes no mention of the loss of Palestinian lives in the ongoing conflict. Without naming Israel, it just talks about the ‚Äúobligation to observe international humanitarian law‚Äù. The only attempt at striking a balance comes from mentioning the need to resume talks to establish a ‚Äúviable State of Palestine‚Äù.

And even this statement, that offers little to the Palestinian people, seems to be consciously delayed. It‚Äôs the immediate solidarity shown with Israel, by way of the tweet and the phone call made by Prime Minister Modi to Benjamin Netanyahu, which again emphasised that ‚ÄúIndia stands firmly with Israel‚Äù, that has registered as India‚Äôs essential response.

The fear is that this lack of nuance may have been intended, and that the Indian government may have erred in doing so.

Read more at thewire.in

A 6-year-old boy was killed and a woman critically injured when they were stabbed by a man who targeted them because they were Muslim in southwest suburban Plainfield Township, police said.

The woman, 32, called 911 Saturday morning and told dispatchers that her landlord was attacking her with a knife, the Will County Sheriff‚Äôs Department said. Police found the woman and the boy, 6, with multiple stab wounds ‚Äî the boy had 26 stab wounds, according to an autopsy.

They were both transported to a nearby hospital, where the boy was pronounced dead. The woman was in serious condition, according to Ahmed Rehab, executive director of the Council on American-Islamic Relations-Chicago. 

Police found the suspect, 71-year-old Joseph Czuba, outside the residence and took him into custody. Czuba was charged with first-degree murder, attempted first-degree murder, two counts of a hate crime and aggravated battery with a deadly weapon. 

Authorities said both victims were attacked because of their religion and the war in Israel.

New Delhi: In the midst of the worsening Israel-Palestine conflict, football, a sport celebrated for its universal appeal, has found itself trapped in political controversy and division. The conflict‚Äôs deep-rooted tensions have transcended international borders, affecting players, fans, and sports organisations.

The FIFA World Cup hosted by Qatar last year witnessed a show of pro-Palestinian solidarity. The most significant being the celebration by Morocco‚Äôs players after their historic win against Spain to enter the quarter-finals of the World Cup. After the win, players celebrated by raising the Palestinian flag. Fans displayed ‚ÄúFree Palestine‚Äù signs in the stands and on stadium walls. In another instance during the France-Tunisia game, a fan managed to get onto the field, waving the Palestinian flag.

The stadiums in Qatar during the World Cup found a place for Palestinian flags, fans came wearing Palestinian armbands and black-and-white headdresses. Some Israeli TV reporters faced open hostility. FIFA struggled to hold the line between sports and politics.

Now, a year on, with a battle raging, football is again on the frontline.

The Libra New moon/ Solar eclipse is bringing a powerful portal to set your intentions to bring more peace and harmony to your relationships. 
To stop giving your power away and to speak your truth.
It‚Äôs time to set your intentions to how you want to be in your relationships.
What qualities do you associate with Libra? Balance, harmony, committed partnership, fairness, beauty, open-mindedness, justice, nonviolent communication, diplomacy and peacefulness probably come to mind.
But Libra also has a shadow side. The co dependent, indecisive, not speaking its truth therefore creating passive/aggressive reactions. Libra also has the need for external validation and the darker qualities of its polarity, Aries: selfish, reckless and ruthless competitiveness. The war lord, ruled by Mars.
Mars just entered Scorpio, while the portal for balance and peace is open. Mars in Scorpio is relentless, laser focused and ruthless about getting his way.
So on the one hand we have an energy that is asking for peace and balance, and on the other hand we have an energy of darkness and conflict.
How can we bridge the gaps between these opposing energies?
Between us and others?
What is justice?
What is fairness?
Can we bring peace and harmony into our relationships?
It all starts deep within our consciousness, our beliefs.
At this time of adversity and uncertainty, balance is an inside job. It always is.

Koreans are divided over the ongoing military conflict between Israel and Palestinian Islamist militant group Hamas, with people expressing differing views on the root cause of Hamas' attack and which side is responsible for the current violence in the Middle East.

On Sunday afternoon, around 200 people gathered in the streets of central Seoul's Itaewon neighborhood, calling for an end to Israel's military action, in a rally organized by the Workers‚Äô Solidarity Youth Group. It was the second pro-Palestine protest organized by the progressive youth group after the first one at Gwanghwamun, downtown Seoul, last Wednesday.

"Today's rally was organized together with Palestinian residents living in Korea, and joined by Korean and foreign residents who support Palestine in its fight against Israel," Park Hye-shin, a member of the activist group, told The Korea Times.

The participants marched down the street chanting "Free Palestine!" and demanding the Israeli government stop its military action in the Gaza Strip.

Iconography as POETRY | ‚ÄúThe painting of images in the Greek artistic tradition is generally similar to writing and much closer to poetic art. This is because, in this tradition, painting was not understood as an objective, correct representation of the randomness of the reality of phenomena but as an attempt to reconstruct the world based on an inner reason. In this way, an image, a true jewel of the world, is presented to the Church of the community.
The images, therefore, come from within, from the mind and soul of the artist; they are not just a matter of the eye but "mental assumptions." They are not mechanical "correct constructions" that coldly represent reality. Even if the forms used by art mimetically simulated the world of phenomena (Hellenistic naturalism), what constituted the image was its inner origin, i.e., the artist's person.
Based on these data, we can say that in the Greek artistic tradition, the image was, and remained until the end, i.e., until the folk painter Theophilos, writing, a poetic record that describes phenomena, conveys information, ideas, and emotions, the drama and joy of life, but above all the life experience of the writing poet.
Painting in the Greek tradition is a poetic event in lines and colors.
Inherent in this Greek visual tradition was the art of church icons (what we now call iconography).
Thus, the iconographers - hagiographers - write images that are not "naturalistic" portraits, showing cold and objective phenomena, but pictures of inner progress, poetic events that record persons and things within an experience of the Church, within an understanding of "communion in paradise." ~ George Kordis

Icon of Christ and St. John the Forerunner from the ‚ÄúWhite Space Conflict Series‚Äù by the hand of George Kordis (@gkordis).

McDonald's is facing heat following its announcement to provide free meals to Israeli soldiers amid the ongoing conflict with Hamas.

 McDonald's Israel took to Instagram to announce that it had provided thousands of free meals to both hospitals and members of the Israel Defence Forces.

In their statement, McDonald's Israel mentioned, "Update that already yesterday we donated 4000 meals to hospitals and military units, we intend to donate thousands of meals every day to soldiers in the field and in drafting areas, and this is beyond a discount to soldiers coming to restaurants. We opened 5 restaurants that were open only for this purpose," as per a media report 

In a statement, McDonald's Lebanon said, "McDonald's Lebanon affirms that the position of other franchisees in other countries and territories does not represent the views or positions of McDonald's Lebanon in any way and McDonald's Lebanon is not involved whatsoever in the actions taken in other markets outside of Lebanon. We are committed to our nation and its people with the utmost respect and solidarity."

Taking to X, McDonald's Oman expressed their support for Gaza. On Saturday, they wrote, Oman stands with Gaza. They also added that the company has donated $100,000 towards the relief efforts for people in Gaza. They said, "McDonald's Oman affirms our humanitarian sympathy for our brothers and sisters in Gaza, and we do not compromise on our commitment to the highest of principles and values that thrive in our community. From this ground of sound values and principles, we are pleased to announce that McDonald's Oman has donated $100,000 towards the relief efforts for the people of Gaza, in coordination with the concerned official authorities."

"In conclusion, we stand with Gaza in these difficult times. Let us all combine our efforts and support the community in Gaza with everything we can. We ask God Almighty to protect our beloved country and all Arab and Muslim countries from all the evil and hate," they added.

Tiger II "234" of the 503rd Heavy Panzer Battalion during Operation Panzerfaust in Budapest, Hungary, October 15th or 16th, 1944. 79 years ago today, Germany launched Operation Panzerfaust to depose the Hungarian Regent, Admiral Mikl√≥s Horthy, and replace him with the pro-German Arrow Cross Party, after Horthy announced the armistice with the Soviet Union in a nationwide radio address.

On November 20, 1940, Hungary became the fourth member to join the Axis powers. But in 1944, there were growing concerns within the German regime about Hungary's potential for negotiating a separate peace with the Allies or switching sides in the war. In March 1944,¬†Hungary¬†was invaded and occupied by German troops as part of Operation Margarethe. A few months later, in October 1944, Horthy made a radio broadcast that an armistice had been signed with the Soviet Union.

To maintain control over Hungary, A. H. ordered Operation Panzerfaust. The operation was carried out by German commandos led by Otto Skorzeny. On the night of October 15, 1944, Skorzeny and his men infiltrated Budapest, the Hungarian capital. They kidnapped Horthy's son and forced his father to sign a document abdicating his powers, which paved the way for the installation of a new government under the leadership of Ferenc Sz√°lasi, head of the fascist Arrow Cross Party.

Under Sz√°lasi's rule, Hungary became even more closely aligned with Germany and intensified its persecution of Jews and other minority groups. Between November 1944 and February 1945, Sz√°lasi's militias shot 10,000‚Äì15,000 Jews on the banks of the Danube. Although Operation Panzerfaust had severe consequences for Hungary and its population during the remaining months of the conflict, it was a temporary measure.

By the time Operation Panzerfaust took place, Germany was already on the defensive and facing multiple fronts. The Soviet Union's Red Army was advancing toward Hungary, and Budapest would later become the site of a prolonged and brutal siege. The 50-day-long siege of Budapest saw some of the most destructive urban fighting of the war. The city unconditionally surrendered on 13 February 1945. (Colorized by @julius.colorization)

„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è‚Å†
"Caught in the inertia of abudecay, both silently waited for the other to reach out, unaware that their friendship was fading like the last colors of a sunset."
„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è„Ä∞Ô∏è‚Å†

The slow erosion of a friendship due to a mutual reluctance to reach out first is a modern-day tragedy of pride and missed opportunities. It's like a silent game of emotional chicken, where each person waits for the other to make the first move, to break the ice that has formed from weeks or months of non-communication. Both parties might even spend moments wondering about the other, yet this curiosity or concern never translates into action. The longer the silence stretches, the more loaded that first outreach becomes, accumulating a weight of expectations and fears‚Äîwhat if they don't respond? What if things aren't the same? In this hesitance, what was once a thriving connection withers into a fading photograph, capturing a moment of joy that seems increasingly remote.

Ironically, this kind of friendship attrition often occurs not because of a major falling-out, but rather due to a collection of minor inactions that accumulate over time. And therein lies the real sorrow: the recognition that something meaningful was lost not in a blaze of conflict, but in a slow burn of neglect. This phenomenon serves as a sobering reminder of the active role we must play in maintaining our relationships. Friendships, like plants, require regular attention and nourishment. The tragedy isn't just in the friendship that has fizzled out; it's also in acknowledging that it might have thrived if only someone had taken that first, simple step. To reach out first is not just an act of communication; it's an act of courage, a declaration that the relationship holds value, deserving to be saved from the slow creep of indifference.

#OTD in 1951, the Battle of Heartbreak Ridge concluded, marking the end of a grueling month-long conflict during the Korean War. Spanning from September 13th to October 15th, this battle unfolded along a winding front line running east to west, a few miles north of the 38th parallel, through the heart of the Korean peninsula.

UN and communist forces, engaged in a series of intense and bloody clashes as they jockeyed for control of the twisting terrain. After a relentless 30 days of combat, American and French forces ultimately gained the upper hand, successfully securing Heartbreak Ridge. However, this achievement came at a considerable cost.

Despite their triumph, Sherman tanks struggled to advance through the treacherous Mundung-ni Valley, with 38 armored vehicles destroyed and nine damaged in the process. Both sides suffered heavy casualties, with over 3,700 American and French soldiers lost and an estimated 25,000 North Korean and Chinese casualties.

The profound impact of these losses resonated deeply with the UN and US command, leading to a strategic shift. They recognized that battles like Heartbreak Ridge, though significant, often came at too high a human toll for the relatively modest territorial gains achieved. This realization prompted a shift toward more cautious and deliberate tactics involving air support, artillery, and infantry, culminating in the eventual capture of Heartbreak Ridge in October 1951.

In the first image, taken September 18, 1951, US troops display signs left by Chinese soldiers. #KoreanWar #HeartbreakRidge #MilitaryHistory

Today our hearts are heavy and burdened as we bear witness to the devastating events unfolding in the Middle East.

We ask you to join us in a moment of silence, to hold space for the profound grief and pain caused by the widespread destruction and degeneration of people and landscapes. We mourn the lives lost on all sides of this tragedy that continues to unfold. 

At Farmers Footprint, we stand firmly committed to inspiring will and building capacity to collectively accelerate regenerative food systems. We understand that a regenerative future can only be realized in a world where peace prevails and where we acknowledge that the health of our planet and humanity are intrinsically intertwined. The deliberate destruction of people, place, homes, culture, agricultural lands, water, and soil is an affront to the very essence of regenerative principles.

As @theslowfactory poignantly reminds us, "war is both a human rights and a climate disaster." Today, on World Food Day, we acknowledge the great loss of humanity caused by unrest, as well as the complete devastation of the ecology that supports life in these regions, including their food systems. Food and access to it is a gift, yet the  stark reality is that in regions affected by conflict, food becomes a weapon, a tool of oppression used to starve communities. The devastating impact of war reaches far beyond human lives, decimating the natural world of which we are an extension of. When we scar the earth, we scar ourselves. 

Through these situations, we are shown how food, health, regeneration, war, violence, starvation, and environmental destruction are interconnected. 

In these moments of darkness we strive for a better future, one where we radically reimagine new systems that focus on humanity and nature as a pathway towards peace. Today, may the innocent find solace and safety, and may we collectively work towards a world where the healing of both people and planet takes precedence over destruction. In the midst of darkness, light persists.

"Today the path of peace, which Saint Paul VI called by the new name of 'integral development', remains sadly distant from the real lives of many men and women and thus from our human family, which is now entirely interconnected. Despite numerous efforts aimed at constructive dialogue between nations, the deafening noise of war and conflict is intensifying. 

While diseases of pandemic proportions are spreading, the effects of climate change and environmental degradation are worsening, the tragedy of hunger and thirst is increasing, and an economic model based on individualism rather than on solidary sharing continues to prevail. As in the days of the prophets of old, so in our own day the cry of the poor and the cry of the earth constantly make themselves heard, pleading for justice and peace.

In every age, peace is both a gift from on high and the fruit of a shared commitment. Indeed, we can speak of an 'architecture' of peace, to which different institutions of society contribute, and an 'art' of peace that directly involves each one of us. All can work together to build a more peaceful world, starting from the hearts of individuals and relationships in the family, then within society and with the environment, and all the way up to relationships between peoples and nations." - Pope Francis, from his message on World Day of Peace, 1 January 2022)
