What happened: McDonald's Israel has sparked a global controversy by announcing its decision to provide thousands of free meals to the Israel Defence Forces and citizens during the ongoing conflict with Hamas. #BoycottMcdonalds started trending on Twitter after this, and the food chain has faced much backlash.

Details: Despite the controversy, McDonald's hasn't stopped. They have donated thousands of meals to various groups, including IDF units, the police, hospitals, residents near the conflict zone, and other rescue forces. In addition, the company is offering a 50% discount to soldiers and security forces visiting their branches. McDonald's Israel has established five restaurants dedicated solely to aid and donations for security forces, with plans to deliver 4,000 meals daily. The conflict between Israel and Hamas, triggered by rocket attacks, has resulted in hundreds of casualties and escalating tensions. The death toll has surpassed 1,300 in Israel and over 1,400 in Gaza.

Adding to unease among South Koreans in a conflict-ridden world this year is the recent full-blown war that broke out between Hamas and Israel early this month.

Palestinian militant group Hamas initiated large-scale land and air attacks on southern Israel on Oct. 7. In response, Israel declared a state of war against Hamas and launched retaliatory airstrikes on Palestinian territory.

The situation resonates with South Korea, where tensions persist between the two Koreas, marked by intermittent skirmishes and military incidents over the past decades. 

"The Israel-Hamas conflict brings back memories of the fear elicited by air raid sirens and text message warnings sent this May," said Oh, a Korea Air Force retiree in his 30s, referring to false evacuation warnings sent by the Seoul Metropolitan Government.

One thing I know is that a devastating loss brings about so much change. Life changes in ways people don't see coming.

Stories change in dramatic ways and the grieving are forced to rewrite their personal stories and it can feel unsettling and scary to rewrite a story that now carries so much pain and doesn't seem to have a clear ending in sight.

The early days, weeks, and months after loss and when the weight of grief is so heavy can feel impossible to navigate. Emotions are running wild and often conflict with one another and quite honestly, the shock of loss can leave people feeling lost and numb for a very long time.

Grievers will often struggle to function at the same level as before the loss and to face rewriting their personal story that looks nothing like it did before is overwhelming and exhausting.

Self-care is so important after loss. It's important to get plenty of rest, stay hydrated, and remember to eat as healthy as you can.

It's important to take breaks from the heaviness of grief even if it's just for five minutes at a time.

Know your limitations and remember it's okay to set boundaries. Boundaries that protect your heart and honor the exhaustion you are carrying from one day to the next.

Be kind and compassionate with yourself and especially when you're feeling like no one else understands all you're going through.

Do something special just for you and yes, it's important to let yourself feel and grieve.

I know you're hurting and I know life after loss feels difficult and hard. I know it can feel overwhelming to try and rewrite a story that looks nothing like the one you had planned on and dreamed about.

Hold on and be gentle with your grieving soul as you find ways to rebuild. With time, the fog will clear and you will find your footing inside of the grief again.

I'm always here to listen and I read every comment you share. Sending love. Always.

michele

#grief #griefquotes #griefquote #loss #grieving #lossofalovedone #griefsupport #griefawareness

Luke 19:13 ¬†
‚ÄúAnd he called his ten servants, and delivered them ten pounds, and said unto them, Occupy till I come.‚Äù
This week I have been in several conversations about the conflict in Gaza and the horrific attack on Israel. A continual barrage of missiles has invoked the law of physics, for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. The disdainful, degrading inhuman encounters and blindsided terroristic actions have caused innocent men, women, and children to lose their lives due to others demented disgruntled thinking, driven by an agenda full of greed, disrespect, and self-indulgence.
Our world is shaken and rightfully so. What is the ripple effect? When is enough, enough? Spiritual wickedness in high places is immediately pointing fingers at one another trying to place blame on each other to gain preeminence, position, and leverage for their own agenda. ¬†
Uninformed accusationalists (if that is a word) are trying to bring rationalization to an ever increasing problem in our world, the world of being uniformed. This conflict that only the Prince of Peace can resolve started with the act of Abram and Sarai not listening to the promise of God. The loss of focus on the promise of God has caused a great strain on many. ¬†
Many questions have arose this week due to the upheaval in Gaza. Questions only God has the answer to. Is Jesus about to come? Will this reveal the Antichrist? Will this open the door to the temple being rebuilt? All of these things could take place. ¬†
In Luke 19 Jesus gives instruction in a parable of what we are to do. Occupy until He comes. Take note, Occupy is capitalized. Occupy, takeover, establish, do business, busy yourself. Prayer warrior, keep on praying. Pastor, keep on pastoring. Preacher, keep on preaching. Evangelist, keep on evangelizing. Singer, keep on singing. Father and mother, keep on parenting. Teacher, keep on teaching. Businessman, keep on doing business. ¬†
Our prayer for you this week: May you keep focused on the command of Jesus and ‚ÄúOccupy‚Äù.

A pro-Palestinian group has vandalised the BBC's Broadcasting House headquarters in London with red paint. 

BBC presenter Victoria Derbyshire took to X sharing images and a video of the painted exterior yesterday, captioning it, ‚ÄúJust arrived at work. This is the front entrance to BBC this morning.‚Äù

The group, Palestine Action, has claimed responsibility for the protest, accusing the broadcaster of having ‚Äúblood on its hands‚Äù due to its coverage of the Israel-Hamas conflict. 

In addition to the London headquarters, the group also targeted the BBC's Hanover Building in Liverpool, once again using red paint to symbolise its alleged complicity in Palestinian suffering.

"Palestine Action sent a message to the BBC overnight: propagating false narratives and endorsing Israel's war crimes means you bear responsibility for Palestinian suffering #ShutBBCDown,‚Äù the group expressed via X.

The Metropolitan Police clarified that there is no indication connecting the incident to a protest group and no arrests have been made.

I love this sentiment that I learned from @traumaattachmenttraining ‚Äî> secure attachment is a behavior rather than a fixed quality and we are all born securely attached ‚ù§Ô∏è

This instinct gets lost, however, when you have injurious experiences with caregivers & attachment figures, resulting in enmeshed boundaries (anxious attachment), hardened boundaries (avoidant attachment), or disorganized boundaries (a mixture of the two).
 
A guiding question to help recover this capacity is as follows: ‚ÄúWhat  securely attached response can I choose?‚Äù

Secure attachment looks like‚Ä¶

‚ú®Owning and communicating your needs and feelings assertively & kindly
‚ú®Demonstrating consideration & curiosity for loved one‚Äôs‚Äô feelings & needs
‚ú®Practicing repair instead of stonewalling or fawning
‚ú®Practicing positive conflict resolution strategies instead of shutting down or blaming

Thinking about secure attachment as a behavior rather than a fixed quality can help you find more agency & resilience in engaging in secure attachment patterns.

Envy, jealousy and anger at someone else‚Äôs success comes from competitiveness and the pettiness of the ego.

The ego is small and limited. Being as such it only feels satisfied by seeing someone fall while seeing itself rise. It gains security through shallow experiences and superficial possessions. That is the nature of the ego. There is nothing to be done about it, other than observing and understanding it.

When the egoic process subsides, which may happen only if the ego understands itself, and therefore cannot carry out its own intentions, then something else begins to make decisions in our lives.

That something else is free from deep-seated fear and therefore also devoid of the violence and hate arising out of that fear. It isn‚Äôt self-seeking in nature.  It derives happiness, pleasure and beauty from its own inward lack of conflict. Clarity itself is the source of its security and happiness. No object, or possession or person is central to its happiness.

Such a mind celebrates the success of others. It pushes them forward even if it itself remains behind. It cares not about who overtakes it or becomes more powerful, for power and influence have no importance in its life, only beauty and love does, to which it has unhindered access.

To have such a mind requires us to let go of the rejection and embarrassment of envy too. It requires us to be at peace with it and observe it unfold and reveal its secrets. How trivial it‚Äôs demands tend to be. When we catch ourselves with these thoughts they weaken and subside.

This unraveling ends in only one place -  a place of deep understanding of what it means to suffer, a place of compassion and empathy towards all human beings, and in partaking in others happiness and suffering without hesitation or holding back.

There is always more to see. The path leads inwards.

.

Imagine your children got kidnapped by your neighbor who lives in an apartment building next door. All the other tenants in that building are celebrating the kidnapping as a huge victory. What would you want your government to do? Let's say the government shut off the water and power in the building as a way to try to force the kidnappers to give your children back. Instead of supporting you, the rest of the neighborhood¬†is supporting the kidnappers and thinks you are overreacting and should just accept that your children got¬†kidnapped because you¬†were never welcomed in the neighborhood.¬†

For a second, drop all your other prior biases about who you think is right or wrong in this conflict. Even forget about all the other atrocities that have happened. What are you willing to do to get your children back?

Now if you think kidnapping innocent children is justified, just realize that this justification only continues to perpetuate future atrocities on both sides. So if you are truly for peace, think real hard about your contributions to the conflict with your own justifications. And if your argument is that those children are not innocent, that is just further justification and perpetuation against more harm to children in the future. Because if you can justify this, the other side will be able to do the same.

As parents, we profoundly influence how our kids navigate conflict. Our reactions become their blueprint for handling difficult situations. 

When we respond to them harshly and loudly, we unintentionally teach them to mirror those reactions. But there is another way. üß°

Let's choose the path of patience, empathy, and understanding. 

When we show children that conflict can be resolved peacefully, we empower them to become compassionate problem solvers. Through our gentle guidance, they learn the value of listening, compromise and finding common ground.

PLAINFIELD, IL- A landlord has been arrested for attacking a mother in son in a home this morning.

The boy, who was stabbed 26 times with a serrated knife with a seven-inch blade, was pronounced dead at a hospital, according to the Will County Sheriff‚Äôs Office in Joliet, Ill.

The boy‚Äôs mother, 32, was in serious condition with more than a dozen stab wounds, officials said. She was expected to survive. The authorities did not publicly identify the victims.

citing text messages the boy‚Äôs mother sent to his father from the hospital that were shared with the advocacy group, said the landlord had been angry with what he was seeing on the news.

One major concern is the impact on oil prices, as India relies on imports for 85% of its oil needs. Higher oil prices could lead to increased import costs, fuel/#fertilizer subsidies, and a weaker rupee, which would affect the country's current account deficit and #GDP growth.

In a press release dated 14 October 2023, Senator Penny Wong, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and Pat Conroy MP, the Minister for International Development and the Pacific, jointly announced Australia's commitment of an initial $10 million in humanitarian aid for those impacted by the Gaza conflict.

It said:

Australia will provide $3 million to the International Committee of the Red Cross to fund urgent needs like restoring essential services and providing medical support to victims of the conflict.

Through United Nations agencies, Australia will provide $7 million to deliver critical support including emergency water, nutrition, sanitation and hygiene services, as well as child protection.

Australia will continue to monitor and assess the humanitarian situation and stands ready to provide further support.

Source: https://www.foreignminister.gov.au/minister/penny-wong/media-release/humanitarian-assistance-gaza

‚ÄúI was doing a week long training on conflict resolution using large scale group process. There were about a hundred of us, circled around a few in the centre who were doing a kind of theatrical enactment of a disagreement between oil companies and protestors. It was very fluid and any one of us could join any side, or stand for another voice in the argument at any time. Some spoke up for the investors, the share holders, or the businesspeople, others spoke for people who were displaced by pipelines, or people who suffered health issues. But then things became really interesting when the voices of animals started to speak up, and then the voices of water systems, mountains and weather.

Still though, the arguments were churning on. We could hear and validate points on all sides but there seemed to be no ways to move towards any kind of reconciliation. 

Then - a painfully shy person who had barely spoken all week, a kind of liminal androgynous being who was really hiding at the back of it all, began to quake and shiver and tremble. They rose to their feet and spoke out in a surprisingly huge voice across all the din, fierce and trembling: 

‚ÄúI am the voice of the Earth!‚Äù"

Theyab bin Mohamed bin Zayed has visited the collection centre for the Tarahum - for Gaza campaign at Abu Dhabi Ports Hall in Mina Zayed, where His Highness witnessed the UAE‚Äôs efforts to collect and mobilise relief aid for Palestinians impacted by the conflict in Gaza.

In these times don‚Äôt let the precision of our words overshadow the sincerity of our intentions.

With that said anyone who truly knows me understands my oddly developed appreciation n understanding of the Jewish people and their culture. Growing up in South Florida, I was surrounded by a vibrant community of which I even met some of my earliest ‚Äúbest friends‚Äù

For years we traded traditions and celebrated countless Shabbats, Hanukkahs, n Passovers. Ive worn Kippahs, joined in prayers, and even frequently found the Afikomen for big üí∞ (iykyk). So, please know everything I express is rooted in love, firsthand experiences, and a 'general' understanding.

In 2016, myself and a carefully chosen group took a 10-day journey to Israel to deepen our knowledge of a people who, like the African American and Arab community, have also endured profound challenges throughout history. We explored the entire country, guided by amazing representatives who welcomed our probing questions, even if their answers were as complex as the questions themselves.

Ive stood in Jerusalem where the Jewish and Arab territories meet, feeling the undeniable tensions. Ive driven along the Gaza border, to the sounds of explosions as reminders of the conflict's daily reality.

These recent weeks have weighed heavily on my heart. Seeking answers has only deepened my confusion and inner turmoil. The feeling of helplessness in the face of such a complex situation is overwhelming. Over the years, I've forged countless relationships with remarkable individuals who proudly represent both sides. And I can say unequivocally that the decisions made by Hamas are not reflective of 'my friends,' just as the decisions made by the Israeli government do not define 'my friends.'

I have faith in the moral compass of the people I hold dear. Even when objectivity can understandably be clouded by emotions, families, and lives hanging in the balance. I pray that the purity I've witnessed in their hearts remains steadfast.

Understanding my words won't resurrect those lost or halt bullets flying from either side. Please know where my heart lies and where my hopes for the future reside. üáÆüá±üáµüá∏

In a heartfelt expression of unity, dozens of supporters of the Jewish community held a vigil Thursday evening to stand in solidarity with those affected by the war between Israel and Hamas.‚Å†
‚Å†
Religious leaders of different faiths gathered around 7 p.m. at the Southwest Orlando Jewish Congregation to lead prayers for lives lost and those that still need protection amid the devastation that followed a brutal attack launched by Hamas on Israel over the weekend.‚Å†
‚Å†
At the vigil Harrison Shames, with the Jewish National Fund USA Orlando, said the fund had started a $10 million campaign to help Israel arrange transportation, resources, psychological treatment and emergency housing for families impacted by the conflict.‚Å†

I've been overwhelmed with messages and calls inquiring about my stance on the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestine. Let me make it clear that I stand in solidarity with the Palestinian people, whose fundamental quest for liberation resonates deeply with the struggles of Black communities all over the country. I'm going to always be Black First. And you can still be Black First and still recognize the humanity in others and join forces to defeat the common enemy, without diminishing your love for your race first. It's disheartening to witness some individuals who claim to champion Black consciousness distancing themselves from this support and claiming it's unrelated to our cause. However, it's essential to recognize that today it's Palestine, and tomorrow it could be Black Americans facing similar challenges. Many of the revolutionary and Black-conscious leaders we often draw inspiration from have a history of standing in unity with the Palestinian people. In the words of Huey P. Newton, "We must think globally and act locally."

Written By Rahiem Shabazz on 10/15/2023

The Ministry of Health in the #Gaza Strip reported that the number of Palestinian casualties resulting from the occupation's aggression on the territory over the course of eight days has now exceeded the total number of casualties during the 2014 conflict with the Israeli Occupation, which lasted 51 days.

On Sunday, the ministry highlighted that this rising death toll is a stark indication of the Israeli Occupation's ongoing atrocities against the Palestinian people and is emblematic of a pattern of ethnic cleansing.

According to the most recent figures released by the Palestinian Ministry of Health, the current number of casualties in the Gaza Strip has reached 2,329 martyrs, including 614 children, 370 women, and over 9,042 individuals wounded.

In the 2014 war, a total of 2,322 #Palestinians lost their lives, including 578 children, 489 women, and 102 elderly individuals, as documented by official statistics from the Palestinian Ministry of Health.

The Pentagon has ordered a second carrier strike group to the eastern Mediterranean Sea, according to two US officials, as Israel prepares to expand its Gaza operations.

The US warships are not intended to join the fighting in Gaza or take part in Israel‚Äôs operations, but the presence of two of the Navy‚Äôs most powerful ships is designed to send a message of deterrence to Iran and Iranian proxies in the region, such as Hezbollah in Lebanon.

The first carrier strike group, led by the USS Gerald R. Ford, arrived off the coast of Israel earlier this week.

Now the USS Dwight D. Eisenhower strike group, which deployed Friday from Norfolk, Virginia, is headed to the eastern Mediterranean. 

The aircraft carrier was initially set to move toward the US European Command, but the officials said it will now head for the waters near Israel.

It is unclear at this point how long the Ford will stay in the region once the Eisenhower carrier strike group arrives, one official said.

The Eisenhower is the flagship of the carrier strike group, which will be joined by a guided-missile cruiser and two guided-missile destroyers, according to the Navy.

The Biden administration made clear that the carrier, and its accompanying force, are not there to engage in combat activities on behalf of Israel but rather to deter others from entering the conflict, including Hezbollah. üé≠üé§

‚ÄúI appreciated that you used your podcast to share how you are struggling, and have a true moment of silence. FLTR has always been a humanizing force in the running community (elites are just like us), and starting this week's episode in that way was humanizing in a very different sense. You'll probably have some angry folks, because everything on the internet is polarizing.

Maybe that moment of silence needs to stay. It got me to pause, and it probably got others to do the same. Pause, reflect, wonder what they can do differently.‚Äù

I got this (abridged version of a) note from an old colleague and friend. It stopped me square in my tracks and made me think about the words I‚Äôm putting out into internet land. 
Many things can be true at the same time. I firmly support Israel defending itself. I also feel deeply for the extreme loss of life in Gaza, as well as in Israel. I also acknowledge none of us are military experts and probably only know 1% of what‚Äôs going on. At the same time, it does feel like Israel got baited into an overreaction and now the world hates Jews even more because they see Israel and Jews interchangeably. 

Most people don‚Äôt know that most Jews don‚Äôt support the right wing government currently in place in Israel. Most people have never spoken with an Israeli or a Palestinian who lives this struggle every. single. day. 

I don‚Äôt have any answers. I‚Äôm just telling you that if you‚Äôve just learned about this conflict in the last week, please trust that there are plenty of nuances you don‚Äôt know and it‚Äôs not binary. And that most Jews (and Palestinians!) are good people who want the suffering and war to end once and for all. 

I cannot explain to you the pride and privilege I experienced my first (and every) time in Israel. To feel like I truly belonged. To feel that I am welcome, and the part of me that is a minority in just about every place besides synagogue is *welcomed* and not questioned.

Continued in comments, photo from today‚Äôs run where I hammered an all out mile because I needed to feel something physical.

Nestled within the Triglav National Park, one of Europe's most beautiful rivers flows with a mesmerizing emerald hue and lively rapids in its upper reaches. üçÉüíß
üèîÔ∏è Meet the Soƒça River, a 137 km long alpine gem with a mysterious karst source in Trenta, right at the foothills of the mighty Julian Alps. Its vivid emerald waters wind through stunning landscapes, making it a true natural treasure of Slovenia. üåç
üåç During World War I, the Soƒça Front witnessed fierce battles between Italian and Austro-Hungarian forces. The riverbanks were a theater of conflict, and the surrounding landscapes bear the scars of that turbulent time.
üìú It was here that renowned Slovenian poet Simon Gregorƒçiƒç found inspiration for his powerful works. His verses, deeply connected to the Soƒça River and the dramatic events of the war, continue to resonate with readers today.
üèîÔ∏è This river's serenity today belies the echoes of the past. It's a place where nature and history intersect, reminding us of the enduring spirit of this region.

üì∏ Depositphotos

#SoƒçaRiver #WorldWarIHistory #SimonGregorƒçiƒç #TriglavNationalPark #Slovenia

‚ÄúCan you post the same thing for innocent who are killed in Gaza?‚Äù

I apologise for the delay in addressing this. After the horrific attack last weekend by Hamas terrorists against Israeli citizens, I wrote that the consequences for Palestinians would be dire and unfair. It has already triggered a war in Gaza, where Hamas leadership does not reside, and I feel deep sadness and anger for those innocent Palestinian people trapped in the battle. I cannot accept Hamas‚Äôs vile onslaught as ‚Äújust revenge‚Äù for the decades of apartheid conditions the Gazan people have lived under. Yet, the right-wing factions within the Israeli government urging punishing retaliation must be resisted, too. Revenge is not just; it is cruel and hateful (and it is not Jewish). This war will not produce an outcome to justify the death it causes. Wars bring about brutality, killings and murders outside the rules of conflict. This battle for freedom to exist on a joint homeland is unlikely to end with a peaceful simple resolution, following decades of complexity. Instead, every day we will read of more deaths. Palestinian and Israeli families and friends will each find out their loved ones have been killed. They will bury their dead side by side using exactly the same rituals, as Jews and Muslims are cousins.

Importantly, each victim is innocent, regardless of whether you agree with their politics or not. That is terrorism, it does not discriminate. 

To the Palestinian and Israeli people, and to my Muslim and Jewish friends who I know are grieving, I hope this war ends soonest.

Thank you to my friend @liztray76 for helping me write this.

"Hace muchos a√±os, estaba hablando de los Cuatro Votos del Bodhisattva con una compa√±era practicante del dharma y, sinti√©ndome un tanto agobiada por cualquiera que fuera el conflicto por el que est√°bamos pasando en el monasterio en donde viv√≠a en ese momento, dije algo as√≠ como: ‚ÄúNo s√© muy bien c√≥mo acab√© siendo monja. A menudo no quiero tratar con la gente‚Äù.

‚ÄúPero, tomas esos votos todas las noches‚Ä¶‚Äù dijo mi amiga, frunciendo. ‚Äú¬øC√≥mo cre√≠as que ibas a salvar a todos los seres sin tratar con ellos?‚Äù

‚ÄúBueno‚Äù, respond√≠, ‚Äúcomo que eso no lo tom√© en consideraci√≥n‚Äù."

"Many years ago, I was discussing the Four Bodhisattva Vows with a fellow dharma practitioner and‚Äîfeeling a little put upon by whatever conflict we were having at the monastery where I lived‚ÄîI said something along the lines of. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not quite sure how I ended up as a monk. The top US diplomat met the Saudi royal in Riyadh in a critical diplomatic engagement as Israel prepared to launch a ground assault in the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip and Washington worked to contain the conflict.

"Very productive," Blinken replied to a question from a reporter as he returned to the hotel where the US delegation was staying.

Life is all about relationships and the quality of those connections. Whether with family, partners, friends, colleagues or, most importantly, yourself, if you can get those relationships on a functional and even keel, then the other tricky stuff that life throws your way becomes easier to manage. 
In this warm, practical and witty book, psychotherapist Philippa Perry shows you how to approach life's big problems. How do you find and keep love? What can you do to manage conflict better? How can you get unstuck and cope with change and loss?
What does it mean to you to be content? Are other people just annoying or are you the problem?

Perry's compassionate advice comes with a healthy dose of sanity and might be just what we all need.

Note to us. Stop doom scrolling. 

I was sick for the past week and during that time consciously chose to put down my phone, step away from IG and heal my body. 

As I return to this digital community, my mental health is rapidly declining due to the ongoing conflict, lack of humanity, and aggressive energy of people on this platform. 

I believe in being informed and taking action to fight for the liberation of the oppressed. In sharing ways you can help and combatting misinformation. 

I also know that we will not save anyone by constantly checking, responding, passively viewing others hot takes or grand statements. 

This is just a reminder to breathe. To walk outside and let the sun hit your face. To hug a friend, family member or a tree to self soothe.

Take a moment. You‚Äôre doing the best you can. 

B R E A T H E 

Posted @withregram ‚Ä¢ @thehealher Pause on purpose 
Set time aside for yourself
Recenter, rebalance, refocus 
Relax, relate, release

Me and @jaylesoleil of @fuckingcancelled are joined by @kaichengthom to discuss conflict and cancel culture on the Left, at this important and timely event hosted by @seizeconcordia. The link to register is in my bio or go to conflictcancelculture.ca. The event is free but you need to register to hold your spot. If we want to organize to win, we need to learn how to be together. Activists and organizers on the Left are notorious for letting interpersonal conflicts become cancellation campaigns. Spectacles of online harassment and community exile prevent conflict resolution and tolerance for disagreement. This damages our mental health, our relationships, our communities, and our capacity to organize for the world we want. Kai Cheng Thom, mediator, educator, and author of I Hope We Choose Love and Falling Back in Love with Being Human, is joined by Clementine Morrigan and Jay Lesoleil, writers, educators, and co-hosts of the Fucking Cancelled podcast, to discuss conflict and cancel culture on the Left.

It has been 6 months since fighting broke out in Khartoum, Sudan, triggering the world‚Äôs fastest growing displacement crisis. ¬†

The impact of the fighting on the country's health service, infrastructure and agriculture is enormous. We know that at times of extreme crisis like this, it is the needs of women and girls that go most overlooked, putting them at greater risk of experiencing physical and sexual violence and trafficking. ¬†

That‚Äôs why we have mobilized our Conflict Response Fund to support two local women‚Äôs rights organizations who are working hard to meet the most urgent needs of women. ¬†

There are no ‚Äúright words‚Äù at a terrible time like this‚Äînot on social media. I refuse to pretend that social media is the real world. It‚Äôs a digital, virtual representation, manipulated by algorithms, controlled by a couple megalomaniac men. Sometimes I feel like this platform isn‚Äôt worthy of our true, heartfelt emotions. But I‚Äôll try to share my feelings here anyhow. 
 
I am utterly devastated by anti-Semitic terrorism. To see this kind of hate in my own lifetime, in my children‚Äôs‚Äô lifetime, is terrifying. The extreme violence and peoples‚Äô willingness to disregard it shows us that anti-Semitism is raging as it always has.
 
The politics and power and hate of the Israel/Palestine conflict is beyond me. I‚Äôm just sharing my feelings as one person. 
 
No people should be oppressed, not anywhere in the world. Seeing children hurt and killed is devastating to see anywhere, in any country, on every continent. I want Palestinian people to be free. I want Israelis to be free. I want human beings around the world to have their basic human rights and be free from war, hunger, and oppression. No countries should ever commit war crimes‚Äîit makes the entire world unsafe. 
 
I just hope that we can all see each other‚Äôs humanity right now. I hope we can all extend to each other love, respect, and patience. I hope we can remember that we‚Äôre witnessing horrors we are not built to withstand. We‚Äôre all doing our best to make sense of this, to take care of ourselves and our loved ones while the unthinkable happens. It‚Äôs so painful to be human, but we can make it a tiny bit easier by extending love to each other. 
 
It doesn‚Äôt take a lot of bravery or effort to post something to social media. It‚Äôs a little digital box on a screen. So besides sitting with our tiny digital windows to the world, watching the screen in horror and rage, I hope we can all use our energy to take long, deep breaths, and give someone a hug or a phone call. Help them feel less alone with the horror. 
 
I‚Äôm sending my sincere love to everyone I know‚Äîwhether you feel detached from everything that‚Äôs going on, or you feel aligned with a ‚Äúside,‚Äù or you feel enraged, or you are just in pain. I‚Äôm sending you love.

üíî The current situation in Gaza (Palestine) is truly heart-wrenching! What is unfolding there goes against the principles of international human rights and humanitarian law.

While it is important to combat the heinous terrorist organization of Hamas with full force, it is equally crucial to ensure the protection of civilians, both in times of peace and war.

Sadly, a new generation of innocent Palestinians, like their parents, are being forcibly displaced from their homes and are once again becoming refugees. Their suffering seems never-ending, as Gaza, the largest open-air prison, is tragically turning into a graveyard.

It is imperative for the international community, including the EU, to call on all parties to end violence against all civilians in both Israel and Palestine. This will help pave the way for a two-state solution, where two democratic states can peacefully coexist, ensuring peace and security for all.

Until now, I must say that some in the the EU Commission have failed to stay on the right side of history - side of peace, protection of civilians and anti-extremism - especially the president of the EU Commission @ursulavonderleyen and the Neighborhood Commissioner Oliver V√°rhelyi have been disappointments. Thanks to Vice President- High Representative for Foreign and Security Policies @josep_borrell_f and the Crisis Management Commissioner Janez Lenarƒçiƒç for being the voices of reason during tough times like this.

üëâüèº Also Charles Michel, President of the European Council, is a voice of reason and important actions. Via the link in my bio, you can find his statement and invitation to an emergency meeting with the member states on October 17.

I stand in solidarity with the people of Israel and Palestine, who deserve peace, security, and harmony in their lives ‚ù§Ô∏è

ISRAEL'S INTEL FAILURE IS BAD FOR BUSINESS:

The sheer scale and intensity of the Palestinian resistance's Operation Al-Aqsa Flood took Israel and the world by surprise last week. Even seasoned western intelligence agency veterans, who possess intimate knowledge of Israel's surveillance capabilities,¬†struggled¬†to provide any plausible explanation for the glaring security gaps.¬†

Academics with decades of research on the conflict, also admitted they are none the wiser: ‚ÄúHonestly I have no f'ing clue what's going on. What this means. Or where this heads. Literally anything is possible,‚Äù¬†tweeted¬†an Associate Fellow at ‚Äúthe world's oldest and the UK's leading defense and security think tank,‚Äù the Royal United Services Institute (RUSI).¬†

US officials were notably¬†evasive¬†when asked if this amounted to an epic "intelligence failure." In the beautiful dance of life, we often forget that every relationship we forge is like a mirror. 

The joyous moments illuminate our path, revealing the brilliance within us. These interactions remind us of our capacity for love, compassion, and kindness. They affirm that we are beings of light, capable of radiating warmth and positivity into the world ‚òÄÔ∏è

Yet, in the very same mirror, we also encounter our shadows. The moments of tension, conflict, and discomfort act as a stark reminder of our imperfections. They unveil the layers of our fears, insecurities, and unresolved wounds. These shadows can be unsettling, but they are a crucial part of our growth journey üåë

Instead of shying away from our shadows, we should welcome them as opportunities for self-discovery and transformation. 

When we confront our insecurities and fears, we have the chance to heal and evolve. 

So, let's cherish every relationship as a mirror. Let's celebrate the moments of light and use them to inspire and uplift. And let's honor the shadows as teachers, guiding us towards deeper self-awareness and authenticity üíñ

In the end, it's the interplay of light and shadow that makes our relationships beautiful, complex, and profoundly human.

With an Israeli ground offensive looming, U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken reaffirmed in some of his strongest language to date that Washington would stand with Israel ‚Äútoday, tomorrow and every day‚Äù in a partnership of shared democratic values, but that Israel must take ‚Äúevery possible precaution to avoid harming civilian.‚Äù He leveled no direct public criticism of Israel or its bombing campaign that has killed civilians in Gaza. ‚Å†
‚Å†
From Cairo, where President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi conveyed his criticism, Blinken went to Jordan and planned to return to Israel on Monday, carrying to Israeli leaders the feedback he received in a rush of meetings with leaders throughout the Arab world. ‚Å†
‚Å†
His second visit to Israel in recent days will come amid heightening fears that a looming Israeli move into Gaza could spark a wider war with devastating humanitarian consequences, a growing concern for the Biden administration. ‚Å†

Six months ago, war broke out in #Sudan. Since 15 April, the conflict has claimed over 9,500 lives, while more than 5.5 million people have fled their homes because of the fighting. 

In August, we opened a new surgical Centre in #Khartoum to provide urgent care to those who cannot receive it in other facilities. Here we receive people burned by explosions, wounded by bullets and mines, but also patients injured in accidents or by civilian trauma. Since opening the Centre, we have treated more than 500 people. 
 
We continue cardiac surgery and cardiology at the Salam Centre even though it is becoming increasingly difficult for patients to travel. In general, it is difficult to get supplies of even essential goods, fuel and medicines; every day there is a new difficulty, in addition to deteriorating security conditions. 

This war attracts few headlines, but it has already triggered a massive humanitarian crisis. 

We will remain here. We are not abandoning Sudan.

Pope Francis called on Sunday for humanitarian corridors to allow the delivery of essentials to the Gaza Strip, which is under heavy Israeli bombardment following a bloody attack by its rulers, Hamas.

Alarm has grown about a humanitarian crisis in Gaza, where Israel has cut off water, food and power, vowing to maintain the complete siege until all hostages taken by the Palestinian Islamist militant group are freed.

In the eight days since Hamas gunmen killed more than 1,300 Israelis in their surprise onslaught, Israel has responded with a devastating bombing campaign that has claimed over 2,300 lives in Gaza.

"Humanitarian law must be respected, especially in Gaza, where it is urgent and necessary to guarantee humanitarian corridors and help the population," said the Pope after his traditional Angelus prayer in Rome's Saint Peter's Square.

"I strongly urge that children, the sick, the elderly, women and all civilians should not fall victim to the conflict", he added.

TULSA, Okla. -- A local Rabbi and a Muslim interfaith leader spoke to FOX23 about how they are comforting their respective communities and each other amid what is happening in Israel and the Gaza Strip on Friday.

A week after Hamas attacked Israel, Rabbi Dan Kaiman, who serves as Principal Rabbi at the B'nai Emunah Synagogue got a special visit from his good friend from the Muslim faith, Aliye Shimi.

Aliye Shimi is a member of the Muslim faith and the executive director of Tulsa Metropolitan Ministry, an interfaith organization.

"I brought him some baklava from Shatila,‚Äù Shimi said. ‚ÄúSo, Shatila is actually the name of a refugee camp in Palestine."

Shimi and Rabbi Kaiman both serve in Tulsa Metropolitan Ministry.

"We're both minorities, and it means that we know each other, and we know each other‚Äôs experiences in a different way, and I think that it actually helps create a different type of solidarity and understanding," Rabbi Kaiman said.

They said that's been especially important over the past week with what's been playing out in Israel and the Gaza Strip.

‚ÄúThis conflict has been going on for decades, and when we add political rhetoric to it, it fuels the fire," Shimi said. ‚ÄúIf we could understand that these are human beings lives, innocent human beings, who are on all sides of the situation, and if we can just humanize it for people, that would help the situation."

They said they hope their friendship shines as an example of what could be if people took the time to understand one another, even if they have different beliefs.

"Those differences don't have to divide us," Rabbi Kaiman said. ‚ÄúThey don't have to be something that creates tension and struggle and strife. Those differences can actually be quite strengthening."

Nejib Ahmed, a wildlife photographer and conservationist from Assam has received a prestigious invitation to attend the 59th Wildlife Photographer of the Year event in 2023, hosted at the Natural History Museum, London.

Nejib's remarkable talent has earned him recognition in the Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition, with one of his photographs awarded as ‚Äòhighly commended‚Äô in the photojournalism category.

Nejib‚Äôs image clicked in the periphery areas of Orang National Park which depicted the human-animal conflict has been selected to be exhibited in the coveted museum for the next one year.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a huge honour for me to get the invitation. I‚Äôm overjoyed at this moment and at the same time I sincerely hope my photographs somehow will help in wildlife conservation,‚Äù an elated Nejib who hails from Dalgaon of Darrang district told The Assam Tribune.

This exclusive event took place from October 9 to 11.

The Wildlife Photographer of the Year is a renowned annual international wildlife photography competition organized by the prestigious Natural History Museum in London, England. This esteemed event features an exhibition of the winning and commended images each year, subsequently embarking on a global tour.

This competition has earned acclaim as one of the world's most prestigious, with winners selected from a remarkable pool of approximately 50,000 entries representing nearly 100 countries. The judging process is conducted by a distinguished and professional panel of experts.

The awards ceremony takes place at the iconic Natural History Museum in London, followed by the unveiling of the latest Wildlife Photographer of the Year portfolio, showcasing the winning images.

Subsequently, the high-quality Wildlife Photographer of the Year exhibition opens in London, captivating viewers worldwide throughout the year and attracting over 5 million visitors.

Nejib is a pioneer from Northeast India to receive an invitation from the Natural History Museum to participate in this prestigious event. This recognition is a significant honour and underscores the commendable wildlife photography efforts in the region.

CHICAGO ‚Äì As the Israeli-Hamas conflict continues, the Illinois State Police (ISP) continues coordinating statewide law enforcement communications and activity in response to the elevated level of threats of violence and hate crimes related to the current conflict.
 
ISP reminds the public of the importance of remaining vigilant against hate crime activity and potential terrorism. 
 
‚ÄúEveryone in Illinois- both law enforcement and community members alike- must remain on guard against both terrorism and hate crimes during this period of volatility,‚Äù said ISP Director Brendan F. Kelly. ‚ÄúIf you see something, say something, before it‚Äôs too late.‚Äù
 
ISP continues its outreach to Muslim and Jewish communities in Illinois to communicate with and support religious leaders being impacted by the current threat environment.
 
Intelligence sharing and communication with our local and federal partners continues around the clock with all of ISP‚Äôs assets remaining at a heightened state of readiness appropriate for this evolving and volatile situation.
 
At this time, there is no actionable intelligence regarding any credible mass threats in Illinois. However, the public should report suspicious behavior to their local law enforcement agency or call 911 depending on the level of the threat.  ISP reminds everyone that if you see something, say something.

I condemn the violence against Palestinians happening right here and now. I woke up this morning to see a video of Palestinian students on UT Campus being verbally attacked and brutalized by total strangers for gathering in public. This horrifies me. So did the attack on Nova. Spaces for education and celebration should be spaces without violence.

To my Palestinian friends, I love you deeply. To my Jewish friends, I also love you deeply. I have zero lived experience in your bodies, and I can only imagine how the last week felt. I know many people in my community are scared for valid reasons‚Äîthat the decontextualized dialogue surfacing may lead to more direct and decontextualized violence, victimhood, death and isolation. I see grief for the ancestors, I see grief for those whose lives and livelihoods are lost and taken. I want to validate and hold space for that spectrum of pain without telling anyone how to feel. 

I write this out of hope. Hope for a free Palestine in my lifetime. Hope for an end to the genocide, war and ethnic, cultural erasure that frame this conflict and similar conflicts around the world. Hope for a world that welcomes meaningful nuance in an effort to clarify, not to obscure or make comfortable. Due to the violent nature of what is currently unfolding, I have no idea what those hopes may require, either. I just know that to be alive is to be bewildered by what has come before us and what will come after and that for the short time we are here, we must grapple with the decisions of our ancestors, the power dynamics of our time and work honestly to honor those who are alive alongside us. That is also easier said than done.

For those of us who do not have ancestral or lived experience with this conflict, I hope we will do our part to actively listen and refrain from co-opting pain that does not belong to us. I also hope that we are unafraid to express solidarity for the human rights we expect in our daily lives and that we openly condemn the violence our tax dollars support at home and overseas. I pray for Gaza.

The US dollar touched a one-week high against a basket of currencies on Friday, extending its gains from the previous session when hot US consumer prices data reinforced expectations that the Federal Reserve may have to keep interest rates higher for longer.
The consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.4 percent in September, keeping the annual rate at 3.7 percent, the same as in August, while economists polled by Reuters had forecast it would gain 0.3 percent on the month and 3.6 percent year-on-year.

Data on Wednesday had shown US producer prices increased more than expected in September amid higher costs for energy products and food.

"Traders didn't really believe in the hot PPI for September until CPI yesterday reinforced it," Helen Given, FX Trader at Monex USA, said.

"I see yesterday's big USD move as a correction to the under-reaction to PPI Wednesday," Given said.

The dollar index, which measures the US currency against six of its major peers, ticked up 0.11 percent to 106.63. The index, which jumped 0.8 percent on Thursday, its biggest one-day rise since March 15, is on pace to finish the week up 0.5 percent.

The dollar was also helped by safe-haven buying driven by the escalating Middle East conflict as Israel urged civilians to leave the northern Gaza Strip.

"Our sense is that the greenback's renewed strength in large part also reflects growing economic and geopolitical uncertainty in the wake of the new war between Hamas and Israel," Jonas Goltermann, deputy chief markets economist at Capital Economics, said in a note.

Commentary from Fed speakers is likely to keep the dollar supported.

Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia President Patrick Harker said Friday he believes the central bank is likely done with rate hikes amid an ongoing waning in price pressures, while flagging the uncertainty of how long rates will need to remain elevated.

Ever since learning about the Israeli air strike that killed Issam Abdullah‚Äîand wounded several other journalists in Southern Lebanon, I haven‚Äôt been able to stop thinking about our community of journalists, why we do what we do, and the way that the enormous propaganda and misinformation that has come out of this war and shaped the discourse around it is a sickening insult to everyone who has ever put their life in danger to bring people the truth. 

I cannot believe that 12 journalists have been killed in the past week alone, that people who were alive a few days ago are no longer with us, that we can still even view their Instagram stories sometimes. Dozens of others have been wounded or had to evacuate their homes as Israel bombards, and prepares to further bombard Gaza. Not to mention covering the horrors inflicted on their own communities. 

Rest in power, Issam. My heart goes out to everyone who knew you‚Äîfor everyone else, please remember to always center the stories of victims of conflict, to support journalists battling the disinformation and propaganda shaping so much of our discourse. It's always the innocent who suffer the most. üíî

I'm not Muslim or Jewish or Palestinian or Israeli. I'm not a historian or an expert on Middle East relations. I don't have all the answers or a comprehensive understanding of the complexities and nuances between warring factions and I can't tell anyone how to create peace in the world, much less in areas that have such a long history of pain and violence. But, like all Palestinians and Israelis, I'm *human* and I can guarantee that continuing to kill and maim and hate fellow human beings is NOT the answer, especially when it's innocent civilians and vulnerable groups, such as children, who feel the brunt of their leaders' actions. There has got to be a better way than this. üòî

To all of those on both sides who have lost loved ones, who have been harmed, who have been displaced, who are living in terror of what's happened and what's to come, you do NOT deserve this and I'm so, so sorry. üíî

And to the rest of us, please show some humanity and compassion for the PEOPLE who are suffering, regardless of where they live or who they live under. Creating further division is only driving the wedge in further‚Ä¶it‚Äôs time for unity against hate, against violence, against continued bloodshed. It‚Äôs long past time to break the cycle of cruelty and conflict and work towards peace and harmony.

üëâ The Red Cross said Saturday it was "appalled" by the human misery unleashed by the war between Hamas and Israel, saying its volunteers would not abandon those who needed them most. ‚Å†
‚Å†
It called on both sides to abide by international humanitarian law, protect civilians and allow humanitarian organizations to alleviate the growing levels of suffering. ‚Å†
‚Å†
"The International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement is appalled to see the human misery that has unfolded over the last week in Israel and Gaza," with civilians paying the highest price, a statement said. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Thousands of Palestinians sought refuge Saturday after Israel warned them to evacuate the northern Gaza Strip ahead of an expected ground offensive against Hamas, one week after the deadliest attack in Israel's history. ‚Å†
‚Å†
"Nothing can justify the horrific loss of civilian lives in Israel last weekend... but such tragedy cannot in turn justify the limitless destruction of Gaza," the Red Cross statement said. "We are deeply alarmed by the call for relocation in Gaza. Our volunteers refuse to leave and abandon those who need them most. They must be protected -- so that they can protect others." ‚Å†
‚Å†
The joint statement was issued by the heads of both branches of the Red Cross Movement: Jagan Chapagain of the IFRC and Robert Mardini of the ICRC. (Reuters/AFP) ‚Å†

Exploring Nietzsche's Astrological üåì Chart on his 179th birthday. üç∞ Birthday 15 October 1844 at approx 10:00 AM

üåû Sun in Libra
üåô Moon in Sagittarius
üîº Ascendant Scorpio

Nietzsche's birth chart reveals a dance between his Libran ideals and Sagittarius's fiery, expansive nature. His relentless quest for balance and harmony met the call of adventure, guiding him on a unique path of self-discovery.

üß† Mercury - Mars 
Uranus-Jupiter: The Power of Intellect üåü

Nietzsche was a force to be reckoned with when it came to intellect. His Mercury-Mars conjunction in Virgo ignited his critical and scientific mind. Uranus and Jupiter added a touch of rebellion, pushing him to challenge conventional wisdom and redefine values.

üåä Neptune's Influence: Mystical Musings

Neptune's presence in Nietzsche's third house made him blend philosophy and art mesmerizingly. His thoughts were often elusive, flowing like poetic aphorisms, and his ideas transcended the boundaries of traditional philosophy.

üó°Ô∏è Sun-Pluto Opposition: Battle Within üåó

A profound struggle was brewing within Nietzsche, as seen in the Sun-Pluto opposition. It symbolized his intense battle for power and self-realization, often leading to an inflated ego and a desire to transcend mediocrity.

ü™ê Saturn's T-Square: Isolation and Control 

Saturn's T-Square formation portrayed Nietzsche's inner conflict with isolation and control. He needed to define himself against the collective, embodying the image of an outsider and iconoclast.

üíî Venus-Moon Square: A Complex Relationship with the Feminine üåπ

Nietzsche's emotional sensitivity and vulnerability were reflected in the Venus-Moon square. His denial of the feminine and obsession with masculine forms of power might have responded to his perceived weakness, contributing to his complicated relationship with the concept of love and connection.

My purpose is to inspire people through the inspiration of space exploration and to Aim Higher for a better future. The thing I love about space is not only what we build, but that when we leave Earth it‚Äôs so clear that we‚Äôre all just humans on the same planet who need to take care of each other. 

#OTD October 15, 2015, I was in Israel with Buzz Aldrin for IAC, an Int‚Äôl space conference that takes place in a different country every year. Being in Israel for the first time was scary. People were randomly being stabbed on the street in Jerusalem where we were. Buzz and I heard gunshots outside of the hotel during one of his interviews. We were nervous and scared to go out in public so I didn‚Äôt get to see much of Jerusalem. 

Then the curator of the Tower of David invited us for a private tour. She said she‚Äôd send cars to pick us up and ensured our safety. When we got in the taxi our driver heard our American accents and said, ‚ÄúWhen you go back to America can you please tell people that we‚Äôre not all bad. I‚Äôm Palestinian and my friends are Christians, Muslims and Jews. There are a small group of people making life miserable for the rest of us who get along. Please tell them we‚Äôre not all the same.‚Äù

When we got to the Tower of David the curator took us to a big hall and said, ‚ÄúLast week we had a beautiful musical celebration of many religions and cultures - Jewish, Muslim, Christian, Buddhist and more. I‚Äôm Jewish and grew up in Israel but my friends are from many backgrounds. When you go back to America, can you please tell them we just want to live in harmony.‚Äù

Two different people who didn‚Äôt even know each other pleaded with us to understand that the vast majority just want peace and to have what everyone wants, to be with their families and loved ones and have a good life. 

I pray this conflict ends soon and those who are crushed by anger and grief can move past that into acceptance and compassion for the other side. 

Praying for peace for all. üôè

#spaceforabetterworld #peace #forallmankind #Israel #Gaza

I have purposely kept quiet for a long time on social media. Big big big health issues, life changes, time spent working, juggling depression, sickness, family, and all the things. And I have purposely kept quiet about the Israel/Palestinian conflict because y‚Äôall, know how I feel about this. I don‚Äôt see how keeping all the people in Gaza is any different than Hitler putting the Jewish people in ghettos and then condemning them to death not being the same as Israel bombing the fuck out of Gaza after they kept all of them there just like they‚Äôve always wanted to do. I said what I said.

At this point, winners or losers, my biggest concern is my baby, who has orders to deploy for nearly all of 2024 to parts unknown seeing things in the world no human should ever have to bear witness to. As mothers, we spend our whole lives living for our children, surviving to protect our children, and praying every day that when we wake up, that nothing bad will come to our children because absolutely nothing is more important in our world than our children whether they are one day old or 100 years old. I‚Äôd never want to live a day without knowing I did everything I could to keep my child happy, safe, loved and protected and this is the one time that I can‚Äôt and it hurts all over. So if I‚Äôm quiet it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm praying that between the crisis in two parts of the world that nothing happens to my whole world half a world away.

The Arab-Israeli conflict since the Cold War ‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨áÔ∏è

__
The Israeli Air Force bombardments on Gaza City have killed over 1,900 people and destroyed entire blocks of buildings causing large amounts of rubble - the bombings are what pre-seeds an Israeli Defense Force invasion with tanks and artillery support. 

__
Due to the simultaneous by the militants on October 7th, 2023, in Israel's southern district, they killed 1,400 Israelis (mostly civilians), and the death toll for IDF personnel is over 200.

__
The militants took as hostages over 100 people, including elderly and young Israelis. Since the outbreak of war, the Israeli Defense Forces have mobilized over 300,000 military personnel and hundreds of armoured vehicles. 

__
[That has become] the largest Israeli mobilization since the Yom Kipper War of October 1973 against the Egyptian and Syrian militaries in the Sinai Peninsula and Golan Heights. It‚Äôs another conflict, in the decades-long Arab-Israeli conflict since May 1948 in the Levant and Middle East. 

__
The 'nature' of the Arab/Palestinian-Israeli conflict did shift over the years of the Cold War from large-scale, regional Arab-Israeli conflict ‚Äî to a more local Israeli-Palestinian conflict, which climax in the IDF's full-scale invasion of Lebanon on June 6th to September 1982.

Pune Police Intensify Security Around Jewish Community Amid Israel-Hamas Conflict

Sumit Singh
Pune, 15th October 2023: The ongoing conflict between Israel and Hamas has prompted the Pune Police to ramp up security measures around the Jewish community in the city. The decision aims to prevent potential violent incidents that might arise in the wake of global tensions.

The Jewish community in Pune primarily resides in the Camp, Koregaon Park, Wanwadi, and Koregaon Park areas. Among the notable places of worship is Ohel David Synagogue, situated in the Camp area. Pune Police Commissioner Retesh Kumaarr has issued an immediate directive to elevate security protocols in these regions.

A comprehensive security review was conducted, led by Commissioner Ritesh Kumar, Joint Commissioner Sandeep Karnik, Additional Commissioner of Police (Crime) Ramnath Pokle, and DCP (Crime) Amol Zende. The team assessed the current security arrangements and decided to augment infrastructure to further fortify these areas.

Deputy Commissioners of Police from various departments have scrutinized the security measures in place and have directed local police station officials to maintain a heightened state of alert. A meeting with members of the Jewish community was also held to discuss the protection of their places of worship and other community spaces.

The last several years of playing around with different formats and venues for my photo work largely boils down to a conflict between optimizing for a sizable audience vs. optimizing for a knowledgeable audience, and trying to bridge the gap by nudging people into the latter category via writing.

I want my audience to engage with the tough questions and the messy details of built environment stewardship and related policy. Part of why I started writing about my photos several years ago is because I got sick of reactions like "so rad..." on images of, like, schools that were closed during the Rahm admin and left derelict. Fetishizing visuals without knowledge, or often even respect, for the conditions being portrayed.

At the same time, I don't want my work to exist in a space entirely dominated by enthusiasts or practitioners of the same, who are already read up. I feel a responsibility as a documentarian to bring my audience along for why I choose to capture the scenes I capture, and what significance I feel they hold. And to some degree, that's been successful.

But platforms are often a limiter. Instagram isn't set up as a useful conversational space. Flickr is just photographers talking to photographers. A personal blog isn't discoverable by many of the people who could get the most out of learning about some of the context behind the work.

So I've tried lots of things. I think I'm developing a better muscle for methods of sharing the photos and their stories that construe what I want while still being accessible. But it's a work in progress - what isn't? I can't help but be dismayed when somebody who has followed my work for awhile drops an Instagram comment like "new construction is ruining our city!", but I also know that I ultimately can't control that. Some people just won't engage in the details.

About a month ago, somebody asked me about my work in the context of their interest in built environment anthropology. And I think what I told them at the time, shown in these screenshots, accurately reflects the undergirding philosophy for my photography today. It's just a matter of translating that into visible, readable form.

Farhat Mantoo, Executive Director of M√©decins Sans Fronti√®res (MSF), South Asia, talks about the dire humanitarian and healthcare crisis in #Gaza with Himanshu Shekhar Mishra from NDTV.

The situation in Gaza right now is catastrophic and heartbreaking. M√©decins Sans Fronti√®res (MSF) has over 300 doctors and healthcare workers on the ground, and many of them have lost their homes and families. Our teams are working at three hospitals and a clinic, and we're also providing medicines and medical equipment.

There is a massive influx of patients, many with burns and traumatic injuries that need ongoing care after surgery. 

The hospitals are struggling because there's no electricity, water, or fuel. In fact, three weeks' worth of supplies were used up in just three days.

We urgently need to get more humanitarian aid into Gaza and ensure that healthcare workers can move safely. We urge all parties in the conflict to allow humanitarian organizations to bring in supplies and help those in need.

Click on the link in the bio to watch the video.

#MSF #Gaza #Hamas #Conflict #DoctorsWithoutBorders

Today as some worship, there is war in the land we call Holy. The scenes over this week of children and civilians massacred, entire communities being destroyed have been heart wrenching to say the least. Witnessing these acts and working through the many layers of complex history of this conflict, through the lense of my belief and faith, my prayer and aim is not for retribution or revenge but peaceful resolution. The childhood adage has come to a head, ‚Äútwo wrongs don‚Äôt make a right.‚Äù There have been decades of wrong, my prayer is that righteousness become our desire. My prayer for all the region comes from the words of the prophet Isaiah, 32:16‚Äì18 (NIV): The Lord‚Äôs justice will dwell in the desert, his righteousness live in the fertile field. 17¬†The fruit of that righteousness will be peace; its effect will be quietness and confidence forever. 18¬†My people will live in peaceful dwelling places, in secure homes, in undisturbed places of rest.‚Äù We are all God‚Äôs children! The vastness of this is too much and too nuanced for social media, these are my cliff notes and personal POV.  Psalm 34:14 ‚ÄúTurn from evil and do good; seek peace and pursue it.‚Äù

Secondo le norme del Diritto Internazionale Umanitario, l‚Äôobbligo fondamentale delle parti di un conflitto armato √® dirigere gli attacchi soltanto contro i combattenti e gli obiettivi militari, distinguendo da questi la popolazione, le persone e i beni civili che non devono essere oggetto di attacchi (principio di ‚Äúdistinzione‚Äù).

Da tale obbligo generale discendono:
- il divieto degli attacchi indiscriminati e delle rappresaglie contro le persone, i beni civili e le localit√† non difese
- il divieto di saccheggio
- il divieto di diffondere il terrore tra la popolazione civile
- il divieto di far soffrire la fame alle persone civili distruggendo beni indispensabili alla sua sopravvivenza
- il divieto di attaccare dighe o centrali nucleari per la produzione di energia elettrica, la cui distruzione pu√≤ causare gravi perdite alla popolazione civile.

Al momento, le persone a #Gaza in #Palestina non hanno scelta. 

Senza cibo, moriranno.
Senza carburante e/o energia, non potranno essere curati.
Senza canali sicuri di fuga, non potranno scappare.

La @crocerossaitaliana appella affinch√©:
- siano protetti i civili, gli operatori sanitari e le strutture
- sia garantito un accesso sicuro e senza ostacoli.

Hundreds of Israelis have been killed, thousands injured and dozens still held hostage by Hamas, young children included. At #Medics4Ukraine in the last few months, we have provided our in country expertise to Jorge, CEO at Hands With Heart Foundation a Spanish NGO focused on rehabilitation. 

Hands With Heart had been looking at ways to provide their expertise in rehabilitation to the wounded since early on in the conflict. Our partnership on this first mission supported 27 patients over 57 sessions, including donations of prosthesis for wounded soldiers. 

We are particularly proud of this cooperation and already working on a second mission. 

To date, Medics4Ukraine has provided ¬£ 3.000.000 worth of medical aid and trained around 800 people in combat casualty care.

More than one million people have been displaced in the Gaza Strip in the last week, the UN said Sunday, after sustained Israeli bombardment and warnings about a ground attack.

Israel has massed thousands of troops and heavy weaponry in the desert south of the country, waiting for the green light to go in to northern Gaza.

The army has told 1.1 million Palestinians in the north of the Gaza Strip -- nearly half of its 2.4-million population -- to head south to safety.

The UN agency supporting Palestinian refugees said on Sunday that some one million people had already been displaced in the first week of the conflict.

"The number is likely to be higher as people continue to leave their homes," UNRWA director of communications Juliette Touma told AFP.

Here is what I believe: every murder is a failure of society, not just of the person who committed it. We have all failed when we don‚Äôt give people the tools to resolve conflict without violence or harm. We have all failed when attempts at reaching out‚Äîfor help, for attention, for justice‚Äîare ignored and a person sees violence as their only other option. 

We fail when entire people groups are raised under aggression, fear, oppression, and lack. 

We fail when we teach boys they are owed the attention or bodies or control of girls.

We fail when we teach racism and xenophobia and fear of anyone different from us. 

We fail when we accept war and vengeance as necessary responses to feeling wronged. 

We can do better than this. We have to do better.

Native American artist Allan Houser (1914-1994) was the first child in his family to be born outside the prison camps where his family was detained for decades following the Apache‚ÄìUnited States conflict in 1885. This marble sculpture by Houser, titled ‚ÄúForce,‚Äù depicts an eagle with a tiny dove in its talons and is widely believed to symbolize incarceration and subjugation.‚Å†

Last night, I went to my first show since coming back from Japan last November. When I was in Osaka and Tokyo I made my schedule too tight and many of the women‚Äôs promotions I wanted to see didn‚Äôt have shows (or there was a conflict). With my column, Dream Slam Monthly, at POST Wrestling & working with PWI on women‚Äôs wrestling topics, I‚Äôve been searching for a way to experience women‚Äôs wrestling offline.

I had been seeking something to rekindle my love for going to shows. At @sparkjoshipuro Rising Heat East, I experienced something special in a venue where I‚Äôve seen wrestling countless times. I caught up with friends I hadn‚Äôt seen in ages as well as met some new people. I‚Äôm sorry that there wasn‚Äôt enough time to chat with everyone, but I am so happy for the show I experienced. My heart is so truly full, and I can‚Äôt thank everyone enough. Please come back to Orlando again.

Connection and Conclusion of Trilogy; ‚Üì 

I wrapped a chat with AI about the artworks and ngl might have failed to explain this well; 

 "Dance with Me on Top of the World" initiates our journey with a scene of celebration, setting the tone for a vibrant narrative. In "Act IV, Scene II; Revenge of RED," the story takes a darker turn, introducing conflict and perhaps a quest for revenge. This evolving narrative is visually connected through consistent colour palette, motifs, and evolving characters.

As we progress to "The Protagonist," we witness a pivotal moment in the trilogy. The character we followed through triumphs and challenges faces a brutal backstabbing, not by an external force but by herself. This self-betrayal becomes a powerful metaphor, exploring the internal struggles and complexities within the protagonist.

The title of the final artwork, beginning with the letter "T," introduces an element of intrigue. What is the word that encapsulates the conclusion of this trilogy? How does this final piece provide closure, answer lingering questions, or leave room for interpretation?

With "The Protagonist" as the central figure, facing the consequences of internal conflict, the trilogy reaches its climax. The visual evolution, thematic continuity, and narrative threads create a cohesive and engaging experience for the viewer. The finale prompts us to reflect on the intricate dance between celebration and strife, revenge and redemption, and the profound struggles within the protagonist's journey.

As viewers explore these three artworks, they are invited to interpret, question, and immerse themselves in a world that unfolds through brushstrokes and symbolism. The journey from celebration to self-betrayal to the enigmatic finale encapsulates the complexity of the human experience, leaving an indelible mark on those who engage with this narrative.

The echoes of protests for Gaza ripple across the globe, but do they hold the power to effect change? Amidst the devastation inflicted upon Gaza, the potency of public outcry remains a beacon of hope.

Here's how taking to the streets can indeed tilt the scales:

1. Awakening the Global Conscience: Protests jolt the world awake, casting a stark light on Gaza's realities often veiled by political fog and media misinformation. They're not just rallies but a kind of education, explaining and unraveling nuanced narratives that reach public forums and enter private conversations alike.
 
2. Unity in Defiance: More than expressions of dissent, protests are threads weaving a tapestry of solidarity. They're a united call resonating across oceans, assuring Palestinians they're not just a cause but a shared heartbeat, their voices amplified in unison with thousands of others.

3. Diplomacy Under Duress: Collective dissent transcends slogans, reaching the halls of power. It's a global chorus demanding action, capable of nudging powers that be, shaking the status quo, and potentially charting paths towards a change seldom considered before.

4. Beyond Numbers: Faces of Conflict: Protests paint the human face behind grim statistics. They're storytellers, narrating tales of lives, dreams, and sorrows, reminding the world that the conflict bleeds beyond territorial lines, into homes and hearts in Gaza.

5. Justice's Domino Effect: Gaza-focused protests don't stand alone; they're catalysts. They can ignite wider movements, fanning flames of global advocacy for human rights, emboldening international law, and knitting diverse causes into a shared mantle of justice.

In essence, protests are far from futile. They're catalysts, consciousness-raisers, and connectors ‚Äî a triad that, when combined with sustained political and humanitarian efforts, holds the promise of steering the narrative towards a horizon of hope, justice, and lasting peace.

~ a Jungian perspective on the conflict in the Middle East ~

If you knew this was a dream, if you knew this was nothing other than a curiously strange and transient play of consciousness, how would your perspective change? 

For me, it would become painfully clear that none of these conflicts are separate from me...

None of these conflicts are new either. Humanity has always held these shadows and none of us are immune to the embodiment of what we are witnessing.

Technology and social media act as magnifying glass, amplifying the collective consciousness in our individual psyches. 

And it‚Äôs a lot to take in.

But the parts of us that are pushed into the unconscious don‚Äôt disappear. They actually gain gravity. Obscuring the light of the conscious realm, just waiting to be seen and accepted as part of the whole. 

Becoming conscious in this day and age can be super painful - it requires a more developed nervous system than previous generations in order to process such massive amounts of information and collective emotional trauma.

I stay with the possibility that poison always appears with the antidote close by. If we can acknowledge the poison, and focus our attention on the solution, perhaps it will appear.

There is no way of proving that this is not a dream. If we were lucid, what would the solution be?

#trauma survivors often experience one (or multiple) of four distinct responses ‚Äì Fight, Flight, Freeze, and Fawn. 

Each of these responses holds a unique role in coping and surviving #traumatic experiences. 

‚Üò Fight: When faced with trauma, some respond by confronting the situation head-on. 

‚Üò Flight: The instinct to flee from a threatening situation is a survival mechanism, pushing individuals to seek safety and escape harm.

‚Üò Freeze: Often seen as a physiological response, freezing occurs when the body and mind become immobilized during a traumatic event. It's a form of protective paralysis, allowing individuals to #disassociate temporarily and minimize the impact of overwhelming emotions. 

‚Üò Fawn: #fawning is about seeking appeasement and making connections to ensure safety. Survivors may adopt a #submissive or people-pleasing attitude, attempting to gain approval and avoid harm. 

Understanding these trauma responses sheds light on the #adaptive mechanisms survivors use to navigate their trauma. 

It's crucial to approach each response with empathy, recognizing that individuals employ these strategies to survive and ultimately heal.

Readout of President Biden‚Äôs Call with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority.

This afternoon, President Biden spoke with Palestinian Authority President Abbas. President Biden condemned Hamas‚Äô brutal attack on Israel and reiterated that Hamas does not stand for the Palestinian people‚Äôs right to dignity and self-determination. President Abbas briefed President Biden on his engagement in the region and his efforts to bring urgently needed humanitarian assistance to Palestinian people, particularly in Gaza. President Biden offered President Abbas and the Palestinian Authority his full support for these important and ongoing efforts. 
President Biden discussed with President Abbas U.S. efforts to work with the United Nations, Egypt, Jordan, Israel and others to ensure humanitarian supplies reach civilians in Gaza.
Finally, President Biden detailed U.S. efforts to coordinate with partners to prevent the conflict from widening, and the two leaders discussed the need to preserve stability in the West Bank and the broader region.

Why Barry Manilow? Well, he made the whole world sing. He wrote the songs. He's Jewish of course. You only have to look at him. Like me. Yes you see a Jewish woman. If I died tomorrow everyone would say at the very least one thing probably first or second in the list: "she was Jewish. Because that's what you see and that's a fact. But today it needs qualifying. Contextualising. Sorry but it does. I would say "well, Ish" because right now I feel I'm a bad Jew, the wrong kind of Jew. Many prominent Jewish people do not hide their contempt or veiled criticism of those of us who won't focus solely on the barbarity of Hamas' attack last weekend but who saw immediately it was associated with history and recent Israeli history at that. Try as I might, I cannot and do not stand only with the innocent victims of the terrorist atrocity of 7 October. I cannot turn a blind eye to Gaza. I never could to be honest. I have understood the conflict for a long time has meant being careful to be loyal and truthful to my heritage without being immoral or hypocritical to my belief which is this: I stand with humans who want to try and break a vengeful cycle of hate and death. It means that today I stand up and say I'm Jewish and let me tell you, I cannot go into my ordinary deli without wanting to burst into tears and I cannot sleep well and I feel more Jewish than I ever have in my life. But I do not stand with the vengeful sarcasm of some and they are all over X who sneer angrily and worse at their "enemy" and who list a hierarchy of hate and suffering. Please no: let us be civil and respectful. Let us not return the murder of one child, one son, one daughter, with the murder of another. That isn't who we are. What to do? I'm going to play Barry Manilow is what I'm going to do. Because he made the whole world sing. He is Jewish but he isn't singing a Jewish song. Just a pop song. No-one can shoot a pop song. It lives in our hearts. #sorrow #sing #unityplease
