This week my thoughts have been almost entirely on what is happening in Israel and Gaza and the horror of it all. Honestly most days my head and heart and soul aches from it all. I have mainly kept off social media because to share here can feel like shouting into a void but today I found myself wanting to come here and share so here are my thoughts from my heart‚Ä¶

I grew up in an Islamic community where we always greet each other by saying ‚ÄúAsalam Alaykum‚Äù and in an embrace offer back ‚ÄúWa Alaykum Asalam‚Äù

This means ‚ÄúPeace be upon you‚Äù and you offer back ‚Äúand Peace be upon you.‚Äù

To me this is the heart of our humanity; Our ability to offer peace. 

I have talked with many of my friends this week and in the hurt, the anger, the confusion, and the complexities of emotion I have heard one thing over and over: all we want is peace. 

This war is horrifying on so many levels. Hamas is not the Palestinian people and the Israeli Government is not the Jewish people. This conflict is complex but terror is terror and when I see each day more and more atrocities being enacted on innocent people, my mind races wondering what I can do. 

And the answer that came to me is simple: I open my heart to you. 

I see the pain and fear of my Israeli and Jewish friends and offer you my arms in embrace. 

I see the pain and fear of my Palestinian and Muslim friends and offer you my arms in embrace. 

I see the pain and fear in the world and offer you my arms in embrace.

And in my embrace I offer,
Peace be upon you. 
Peace be upon us all. 

My heart is open.

Strange how our ability to control our mind and situation changes over time and the main reason is people and environment around us. We allow external elements like people and internal elements like expectations and sentiments to make us weak.

I was extremely strong in making deductions and coming to conclusion long while back but then the content and people that you allow in your life awakens a certain part of your brain that tricks you to believe that you‚Äôll feel something new. And that was fall. It was all a trick. 

Although this weak side of mine rewarded me with new experiences which allowed me to feel a completely weak inner self that brought me to a rock bottom. But coming to a rock bottom was an amazing experience of not having to lose anything yet I was so powerful.

I allowed my emotions to control my logics rather than I used to use my logical deductions to control my emotions. As I come back to reality today after 6 years I realise the later is very much less painful (but the first one has beauty of it if you know how to enjoy pain)

There is a war going on, not outside that is merely a geopolitical conflict but inside of you thst is killing you every second. A war of thoughts and opinions and content of people who you have never met and haven‚Äôt lived your life. You are subconsciously using that information to solve your problems which is completely unrelated.

I declare selfawareness as current state of mind. Logical stability and ability to make deductions while staying in the present moment to make decision for greater good which is emotional experiences. ü•Ç

Don‚Äôt try to understand. M very complicated. You‚Äôll only waste your time.

Water: one of the reasons for conflict in the Mediterranean. Those who control the water, control negotiations

In May I had the opportunity to visit Jordan with @oneofmany.studio as part of a residency. One of the intentions was to explore my ancestry, which has parts Iraqi Jew and Chinese. This exploration was through calligraphy. Where I took my childhood practice of Chinese Calligraphy and applied it to text in Hebrew and Arabic with the help of @nourbatyne and @hanagammoh 

By the end of the trip, I felt inspired to not just write text in these languages but to start to combine them into new words. I ended up creating 3 words in Mandarin and Arabic - light, water and the way. This second one is the word water.

For many of us, our ancestry is tied up in many different cultures, languages and borders. I may be a writer, a journalist, an author, but Mercury ‚Äî¬†the planet of communication ‚Äî¬†is as invested in listening as it is speaking. So, perhaps it is as a Mercury-ruled person, that, in times of crisis, I look to respected voices for guidance, reassurance, and wisdom. In the wake of the horrifying events in Israel and Palestine, I‚Äôve been looking and listening to Rabbi Sharon Brous, a leading, ‚Äúsoulful, justice-driven‚Äù voice in the Jewish American community.

In the midst of grieving and contending with fear and disappointment, anger, overwhelm, helplessness and paralyzing sadness as a Jewish American, Rabbi Brous‚Äô words have felt like something to hold onto. I‚Äôm sharing them today, because, with hope, they‚Äôll resonate with you, too.

As an astrologer, I‚Äôve been thinking a lot about the message of the¬†the solar eclipse and new moon at 21 degrees Libra, which was exact yesterday. Libra, ruled by Venus, the planet of relationships, values diplomacy while its opposite sign, Aries, ruled by Mars, the God of War, centers aggression and conflict. It‚Äôs no wonder that, as we grapple with complex, intense emotions and how to best present them to others, many of us feel torn between these two extremes. But eclipses are all about accepting massive shifts, and we all have the choice right now to share our thoughts and feelings in a way that‚Äôs neither candy-coated or combative. Another voice I respect is that of one of my astrology teachers, @rebeccagordonastrology, who writes that the eclipse is asking us ‚Äúto change the codes of how we relate to one another. In order to do that, we must CHOOSE healing versus perpetuating cycles of pain, fear, or animosity. It asks us to do this on the global stage as well as in our personal lives. There is another way and we can change the patterns.‚Äù

I find it heartening that these two women whose voices I deeply respect ‚Äî¬†one a leader in the Jewish community, the other a leader in the astrological community ‚Äî are saying the same thing: that changing the way we relate to one another will, ultimately, lead to healing. Easier said than done, sure, but it also feels like the hopeful message I ‚Äî and perhaps you ‚Äî could use right now.

"OPENING TO THE BODY: Sounds strange. Doesn't it? Yet, most of us have peculiar relationships with our bodies. We are either obsessed with it or have dissociated from it because we live so much in our heads. 

In several spiritual traditions, the body is considered a hindrance to higher knowledge. Some teachings go so far as to say that it is a bag of filth and must be ignored in favor of mind- and intellect-based investigations. This view only creates a deeper conflict between the unity of life we strive to see and our warped, dysfunctional relationships with our bodies. 
What if we came to see the body as it is? 

At its core, the body is a mass of exquisite and dynamic sensations - each a facet of awareness, sweetly arising and subsiding into nothingness. 
Our sense organs are portals to this ever-changing landscape of unimaginable sensuality. And if we are willing to allow the body to teach us, it will lead the way into the pulsating sweetness that permeates creation. 

If we could only see beyond its shape and size or its limitations of flexibility, strength, and fitness, the body could change our relationship with health, disease, ourselves, others, and everything. 

Our very limitations can become doorways to freedom. And this is the secret of Tantra. In this tradition, nothing is filthy or limited. Everything is divine. Everything is in plain sight. We just need to open our eyes."

Kavitha Chinnaiyan

The special flight carrying 274 Indian nationals wanting to leave Israel amidst the Israel-Hamas conflict left for home on Saturday, the second in a day and fourth since the launch of 'Operation Ajay'.

The special flights are part of the operation launched on October 12 to facilitate the return of those Indian nationals who wish to return home following the brazen attacks on Israeli towns by Hamas militants from Gaza on October 7.

The Indian Embassy in Tel Aviv earlier earlier announced that two special flights will operate from Ben Gurion airport on Saturday.

The first flight left around 5.40 pm local time. The second flight with 274 Indian nationals took off at 11.45 pm local time.

The third batch of 197 Indian nationals left for home around 5.40 pm local time (8.10 pm IST).

"#OperationAjay moves forward. 197 more passengers are coming back to India," External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar posted on X.

The Embassy of India in Israel posted on X,"As part of #OperationAjay, Indian nationals still in Israel and wishing to travel back to India are urgently requested to complete the attached travel form."

The Indian Embassy also issued guidelines that " travel slots will be allocated on a 'first come, first served' basis in the 'Operation Ajay' and "In the event of a no-show or refusal to travel after confirmation and slotting, your name will be moved to the back of the queue."

"The Embassy has been working round the clock to facilitate all our citizens in Israel who wish to leave. We have reached out to students, caregivers, and business people. Some of them are actually working with us as volunteers. We urge everyone to remain calm," Ambassador Sanjeev Singla told PTI.

"The Embassy has emailed the next lot of registered Indian citizens for two special flights today. Messages to other registered people will follow for subsequent flights," the Indian Embassy in Israel posted the announcement on X earlier in the day.

Australia is providing an initial $10 million in humanitarian assistance for civilians affected by the conflict in Gaza.

Australia will provide $3 million to the International Committee of the Red Cross to fund urgent needs like restoring essential services and providing medical support to victims of the conflict.

Through United Nations agencies, Australia will provide $7 million to deliver critical support including emergency water, nutrition, sanitation and hygiene services, as well as child protection.

Australia will continue to monitor and assess the humanitarian situation and stands ready to provide further support.

My grandparents lived through the Spanish Civil War. My Abuelita woke up to bombings next door and lost friends and family. 

My grandfather would go on to fight on the battlefield and then spent a long time in one of the dictator Franco¬¥s concentration camps. He developed anxiety, claustrophobia, and PTSD.

That¬¥s largely the reason why I¬¥m bilingual and bicultural - my dad came to the U.S. at 16 because times were dire in Spain. 
‚Ä®Eventually, we moved back to Madrid when I was a kid and I grew up and lived through the transition from a dictatorship to democracy, a failed coup d¬¥etat and terrorism - Supermarkets, buses, and train stations bombed killing innocent people. We learned to keep on going through it all. 

But back then there was no social media to amplify any of it. Now we have access to images of war and terrorism and lost lives. 

Along with that, for those of us not actually in the area of the conflict, which is of course a privilege, there is a threat to our mental health. 

Here are some things we can do to preserve it in a world that spreads news like wildfire and everything coexists - our need to keep on going and our desire to be empathetic and compassionate:

- Routine is Key: When the world outside feels unpredictable, maintaining a daily routine can provide a comforting semblance of order.‚Ä®
- Stay Physically Active: Physical activity can act as a natural antidepressant by releasing endorphins, the body's feel-good chemicals.‚Ä®
- Journaling: Writing down feelings can be a therapeutic way of processing and understanding emotions.‚Ä®
- Limit or Erradicate Substance Use: While it might be tempting to use substances like alcohol as a coping mechanism, overreliance can lead to further mental health complications.‚Ä®
- Hold onto Hope: Remind yourself of moments of resilience and strength, past challenges you've overcome, and that this too shall pass.‚Ä®
Given the dual stresses of global conflict and inner discord, it's more important than ever to be compassionate and patient with yourself. 

Seek out resources and communities that resonate with peace and understanding, and always prioritize your mental well-being. How are you doing that?

Welcome to relationship conflict season! Otherwise known as the Libra eclipse! üåò‚ôéÔ∏è‚Å£
I have been witness and apart of some interesting conflicts lately. And it is so interesting to just witness them as they occur:

I saw a volleyball player blame the loss of a game on a fellow player (who got 5 points single-handedly in one game). That player was reflecting the loss and rejection he felt onto the other player.

I had a family member very upset with me that I didn‚Äôt call or ask about how they were. The abandonment they felt many times in their life was reflecting back to them through me.

I have witness a dear client getting so upset with the atrocities in the news, as a reflection of her helplessness to help people who are innocent even in her own life.

I have a beautiful client trying to reconcile a marriage, but her husband is caught in deep shame and continues to reflect his shame and unworthiness on her every time she attempts a loving gesture.

We will continue have our wounds reflected back to us until we heal them.

For example, if my family member had reached out and said ‚Äúhey! I was thinking about you!‚Äù I would have been so excited to talk to them. But instead it was ‚Äúyou never contact me‚Äù. That‚Äôs right, I don‚Äôt. Because I am busy with my own life. I rarely reach out to people, because my plate is overflowing. But to an unhealed person, that is feels like abandonment, because she already had an abandonment wound. Said another way, she has anxious attachment. So when someone doesn‚Äôt call, she feels like she did something wrong, or that she is not worthy to be chosen. And that certainly was not the case.

So the question is what is being reflected back to you? What are you experiencing that is hurting your heart? Where does that wound really come from? Because it isn‚Äôt outside of you. It always starts from within. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçü©π

Do you think AI is a threat or an opportunity for humanity? How do you think we should regulate and govern AI? Share your opinions in the comments below!

Dr. Geoffrey Hinton, widely regarded as the ‚Äúgodfather of AI‚Äù, has recently quit his job at Google and warned about the dangers of artificial intelligence. He said he was concerned about the potential for AI to surpass human intelligence and control humanity. He also said he regretted his work on neural networks and deep learning, which have enabled the development of powerful AI systems like chatbots.

Hinton said that chatbots could soon overtake humans in the amount of general knowledge and reasoning they possess. He also said that chatbots could be used for malicious purposes, such as spreading misinformation, manipulating elections, or creating sub-goals that conflict with human interests. He said that AI posed an ‚Äúexistential risk‚Äù to humanity and that he wished he had never started working on it.

Hinton‚Äôs views are shared by some other prominent figures in the field of AI, such as Elon Musk, who has warned about the possibility of AI creating a ‚Äúdigital superintelligence‚Äù or a ‚Äúdigital god‚Äù. However, not everyone agrees with Hinton‚Äôs pessimism. Some argue that AI can be beneficial for humanity if it is aligned with human values and ethics. They also point out that AI can help solve some of the biggest challenges facing the world, such as climate change, poverty, or disease.

ü•≥ Today is Ella Belle's 12-ish birthday! 

We adopted Ella on my birthday and the vet estimated that she was between 18 months to two years old, so we just went with two years old and gave her my birth date so we could celebrate together. 

I suspect she's on the younger end of the age curve though. She's still very healthy and spry!

When we got her, neither Woody nor I were home much and I think Eve was a bit lonely after our cat Toby had passed on. Eve wasn't a fan of other dogs, so I wasn't sure getting a second dog was the best idea, but I saw this little one's photo on Petfinder and just had to have her. She was a last minute death row rescue and came with a lot of psychological baggage, fear, and PTSD, but after a few days, she and Eve clicked like magic and they were best friends with never a dispute between them until Eve left us.

Ella's never been quite the same since her bestie passed, but we love this little weirdo very much.

She was such a good big sister when we brought her home a little puppy companion named Abigail Rose to keep her company when we knew Eve would not be with us much longer. Eve showed little Abby the ropes too, but it was Ella who played with her, snuggled her, and loved her until one day the little one had become the biggest of them all and declared herself the queen. Even then, Ella quietly became Abigail's loyal servant though their relationship has not always been as free from conflict as we all would like.

Ever steadfast, my little shadow and protector, I love my little Ella Belle and wish her many more years with us üíô

STARTS TOMORROW! Follow the #VirtualBookTour for In Truth, Madness by Imran Khan @Imranism  @breakthrough_book_collective 

The perfect read for Neil Gaiman fans. 

Meet Malek Khalil, a brilliant reporter with decades of experience in the field, and a man on the edge. Where there is war, natural disaster or political crisis, Malek is in the midst of it, but years of conflict reporting have taken their toll and he is slowly unravelling. 
His colleagues, Neeka and Justin, have noticed a change in him, beyond even his usual vivid imagination. Neeka is especially sensitive, having been his friend and producer for many years, and perhaps knowing him better than he knows himself. Justin, a skilled and brave cameraman, has worked with them for just as long and the three make a formidable team - but they are only as strong as each other - and Malek is fast going down the rabbit hole.

Born a Muslim but an atheist to his core, Malek's voyage takes him around the world and back in time to ancient Babylon, as he finds himself arguing with a God in whom he does not believe. A keen reader, his 'madness' is heightened by a strange book that keeps appearing on his Kindle, telling the stories of people he has briefly encountered during his career.

In Truth, Madness takes place in the Middle East, South Asia and London against a backdrop of war, religion, political skullduggery and emerging love, taking the reader on a tumultuous journey through the most dangerous arenas of modern culture and the ancient world. 

Is Malek losing his mind, or is he experiencing an astonishing kind of truth? 

Our hosts tomorrow will be @fatguyreading and @jlreadstoperpetuity

Credit to @thekoreaherald A total of 192 South Korean nationals returned home early Wednesday from Israel, where tensions are escalating amid an armed conflict between the Jewish state and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas.

A Korean Air plane carrying them arrived at Incheon International Airport, west of Seoul, at 6:08 a.m., after departing from Tel Aviv at 1:45 p.m. the previous day.

It is the first flight that has brought South Koreans back home since the conflict erupted Saturday when Hamas launched a surprise attack on Israel.

A Divided Duty by Ben Vizard

BLURB

1939. 

Declared unfit for active service after the Great War, Richard Hansen feels rudderless and out of place. But when the unthinkable happens and the shadow of a new conflict looms, he is thrust into enemy territory once again for a final, covert mission. 

Devastated and mourning her own catastrophic losses, his wife Emily is alone and adrift in a once-idyllic marriage grown cold and distant. When one day a surprise visitor comes calling she is faced with a choice that may grant her the very thing she has always longed for‚Ä¶ or lead her into terrible danger. 

As Europe goes to war a second time and Richard and Emily‚Äôs paths are wrenched apart, each must confront the ghosts of their own past, battling forces both seen and unseen as their lifelong love is tested to its limits - by duty, grief, time, and betrayal.

REVIEW

I adored A Painful Duty which was book one in this series, so I was so keen to read and review this second book, and, it didn't disappoint in the slightest, in fact, I think I would say this was even better than the first.

It is well written with a compelling story line that continues seamlessly from the end of the first book, and well developed characters that I liked even more in this book and felt like I got to know them even better. It is easy to see that the books in this series have been researched so well, there is so much that is factually correct, however, it isn't bogged down with facts so it feels like a chore to read. It is the perfect bled of fiction marrying with fact to make a perfect read.

This is definitely a heartbreaking read that will have you reaching for the tissues more than once, but trust me it is so worth it. 

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê/5

Failure to conduct end-use monitoring could expose U.S. officials to International Criminal Court liability for aiding and abetting Israeli war crimes
(Washington D.C., October 15, 2023) ‚Äì U.S. law requires the United States to monitor the weapons and munitions it provides to Israel and ensure they are not used to commit war crimes in Gaza, Democracy for the Arab World Now (DAWN) reminded Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III in a letter sent Friday, October 13, 2023. Failure to comply with end-use monitoring requirements not only breaches U.S. laws but also could expose U.S. officials to prosecution by the International Criminal Court (ICC) for aiding and abetting war crimes, DAWN warned.

In a separate letter to ICC Prosecutor Karim Khan on Friday, DAWN asked the Prosecutor urgently to issue a public statement reminding the parties to the conflict of the ongoing investigation there and send an investigative team to the Gaza region of Palestine to document and investigate potential crimes under the Rome Statute.

Below Keegan shares the corners of the globe he‚Äôs seen on his study abroad adventures.

üåé University of Exeter, UK üåé

At the University of Exeter, my short-term exchange program saw me in an ‚ÄòInternational Relations: Security, Conflict and Peace‚Äô unit. This academic experience enriched my understanding of global security and offered crucial insights into subjects such as nuclear disarmament and asymmetric warfare. The skills and knowledge acquired from this unit are directly relevant to diplomatic dialogue and conflict resolution within the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

Exeter is a town with its own unique charm. The Imperial, or ‚ÄòImpy‚Äô, was where we went for drinks, especially to enjoy the spacious beer garden during the United Kingdom‚Äôs 2022 summer heatwaves ‚Äì a typical summer by Australian standards. 

üåé Universit√† Cattolica del Sacro Cuore, Milan üåé

The extensive academic and cultural exposure I received in Italy was invaluable for my understanding of European diplomacy and politics. 

Back in Australia, my studies often framed the European Union as a distant political entity, dissected through the lens of external perspectives. Sitting in a classroom in Milan, however, I could appreciate the tangible impacts of European Union governance, laws, and regulations.

üåé Mahidol University, Thailand üåé

My time in Thailand during a short-term exchange program offered a unique cultural immersion. This provided a cornerstone for understanding the societal intricacies crucial for diplomacy. This academic adventure bolstered both my formal and informal skill sets, especially in the area of cross-cultural communication, a vital skill for Australia‚Äôs diplomatic efforts in the Indo-Pacific region. Supported by the New Colombo Plan, this experience aligns with its objectives of uplifting Indo-Pacific capability in Australian graduates.

üåé What‚Äôs next? üåé

A United Nations Headquarters Study Tour in Geneva with the United Nations Association of Australia (Victoria Division), and Masaryk University in Czechia.

Learn more about study abroad opportunities at link in bio!

Repost @stevendonziger THERE is a dangerous development in the campaign to hold the fossil fuel industry accountable for damage caused by climate change.

While the war between Israel and Hamas consumes the world's attention, the fossil fuel industry is quietly working to delay and sabotage legal proceedings in the US to hold it accountable for its leading role in creating global warming. There are about 25 legal cases pending in US courts brought by cities and states against the oil majors and the industry lobbying group The American Petroleum Institute.

The fossil fuel industry's latest gambit is to try to dismiss these cases by arguing the industry is not responsible for the massive damage caused by climate change because it had no "duty to warn" the public. Industry lawyers cynically claim oil companies had no "duty to warn" because knowledge of climate change was available decades ago -- even though oil majors like Chevron and Exxon tried to deceive the public by hiding that very information. They did this by suppressing their own internal scientific research pointing to inevitable and drastic climate change, while at the same time paying lobbyists at front groups like the Heartland Institute to create "uncertainty" about the issue in public.

A mastermind of the new industry legal strategy is none other than Ted Boutrous of Gibson Dunn, the same fossil fuel law firm Chevron paid to orchestrate my private corporate prosecution after we helped Indigenous peoples in Ecuador's Amazon win a historic $10 billion pollution judgment. Boutrous also represents the New York Times in its media and First Amendment work ‚Äì a clear conflict of interest for the newspaper which might help explain why it never covered Chevron's orchestration of my illegal 993-day detention in retaliation for winning the Ecuador pollution case. Boutrous himself was intimately involved in the targeting of me and the affected Amazon communities of Ecuador.

On this Rural Women's Day, we honour the strong and resilient women living in conflict-affected villages. Their determination and courage fuel their success against all odds.

We're proud that our #EU4Dialogue initiative supports these incredible women, fostering their professional growth, entrepreneurial achievement, and personal development.

As Nana Tskrialashvili from Bershuaeti village says, "This project convinced me that I can be strong. I'm already a fighter, but now I have even more new ideas."

Ekaterine Kobaladze from Khurvaleti village notes: "This project taught me how to stand by people and inspire hope in one another.‚Äù

Through the EU4Dialogue initiative, @euingeorgia and UNDP champion local civic endeavours that empower rural women and youth and benefit hundreds of people across Georgia.

Unforgiveness causes conflict and creates obstacles in your relationship with God. It also undermines your connection with Him and sets you against those who could assist you. Forgiveness is the ultimate key to a life filled with power. 

One's ability to forgive quickly is a clear indicator of their knowledge of God. Whenever you seek God's mercy, He instructs you to begin with forgiveness. Unforgiveness leads to a failure of grace and inflicts more harm than the devil ever could.

Unforgiveness tarnishes your grace amidst blessings. Inability to forgive signifies a lack of understanding of God, as Christianity is founded on forgiveness. Unforgiveness squanders offerings and sacrifices and perpetuates poverty. It hinders your access to financial blessings.

Unresolved conflicts among individuals lead to conflicts between you and God. Bitterness is unproductive, and no one is deserving of hatred. Unforgiveness blinds you to any goodness in others.

Genuine forgiveness is evident when you harbor goodwill, are willing to reconcile, abstain from gossip and revisiting past offenses, extend kindness, and think and speak positively about those who have wronged you. When you continue to act and live as you did before, never harboring resentment, it reflects true forgiveness.

Fellow educators:

Some of the most important lessons our students will learn are lessons that are not about the topic on our syllabi. Students are always observing and learning from how we hold space, how we evaluate opinions and input, how we negotiate and move through conflict in the classroom, how we denounce systemic violence, how we are complicit in systemic violence, how we admit when we do not know something, how we bullshit, etc.

All this to say: address the world we live in.
Teach basic definitions. Pause lesson plans.
Read things together in the classroom.
Process in community Sit alongside the silence.

The most important things we can teach will sometimes never be what we put down on the syllabus.

LET ME BE CLEAR. I do not care to discuss the nuances of this conflict. My heart breaks for every human life destroyed by this tragedy. I am organizing this as a human who loves music and the community I share that love with. Music is a celebration of life. For many of us, it is our most important and accessible form of therapy. For all of the survivors of Nova, they have lost that sanctuary.

As a community, I believe it is our obligation to do everything we can to help our brothers and sisters heal from this as much as possible. This will require months or years of intensive therapy and counseling. 100% of the proceeds raised here will be donated to NovaHelp (www.novasupport.org), an organization committed to providing free mental health services to all of the survivors affected by this tragedy. If you have ever found solace in a warehouse at 4 a.m.; if you have ever watched the sunrise with your best friends at a festival in the desert; PLEASE share this and donate.

I don't care who you are or what your beliefs are. Music is humanity. If you cannot understand that, I have neither the time nor the crayons to explain it to you. Thank you all for your support.

The link to donate is in my bio.

Asiza's story from Chad is a stark reminder of the hardships faced by families escaping conflict. Alongside her husband and three children, she sought refuge across the border, leaving behind everything they knew. The situation in Chad is dire, with a significant influx of refugees and returnees in need of assistance.

Asiza received a ShelterBox tent, which, while a blessing, doesn't alleviate all her concerns. Life in the camp remains challenging, with limited opportunities for her family to earn income, food security worries, and the urgent need for her children's education.

This story underscores the importance of ongoing support for displaced families. Chad and its neighboring countries are shouldering a heavy burden. Let's come together to ensure that families like Asiza's receive the assistance and opportunities they deserve.

Israeli Ground Forces Set To Strike Hamas-Controlled Gaza Strip

Israeli forces are preparing for a ground assault in Gaza as the country hit back for an unprecedented attack on its territory.
Israeli military spokesman Richard Hecht has urged civilians in northern Gaza, where Hamas's leadership is based, not to delay in getting out.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said "more is coming" in Israel's response to Hamas's shock attack last week, according to a video released by his office. "Are you ready for what is coming? More is coming," Netanyahu, wearing a flak jacket, was heard telling soldiers.
Some 1.1 million people - nearly half the population of 2.4 million - live in the north of Gaza, and aid groups have said forcing them to move is an impossibility as the war rages. With food, water, fuel and medical supplies running low because of an Israeli blockade, aid agencies are warning of an impending humanitarian crisis in Gaza. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres described the situation in Gaza as "a dangerous new low".
A potential Israeli ground invasion has also increased fears for the safety of the 150 hostages, including foreigners, that Israel said Hamas captured during its deadly rampage.
Israel has vowed to destroy Hamas, which several Western governments, including the US, have proscribed as a terrorist organisation, and likened to the Islamic State group.
Iranian foreign minister Hossein Amirabdollahian yesterday praised the Hamas rampage as a "historic victory" that had dealt a setback to Israel's occupation of Palestinian territory. Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh and Hossein Amirabdollahian, at a meeting in Qatar's capital Doha, agreed to continue cooperation" to achieve the group's goals, Hamas said in a statement.
US President Joe Biden and other world leaders, have however, warned against any country broadening the conflict.

This @bustle article about the HR-ification of marriage is food for thought. ‚Å£
‚Å£
"I didn‚Äôt think so much about this in those glossy, glowy, early days of my marriage. In the beginning it was much more of a fly-by-the-seat-of-your-pants, figure-it-out-as-you-go adventure filled with trips around the world at a moment‚Äôs notice. And car sex. The idea of having a weekly meeting with my spouse, of using a spreadsheet for anything besides tracking my work expenses, would have seemed absurd and unsexy.‚Å£
But in search of a more equitable, a more fair, and a more palatable union, some couples are opening up about adopting the types of structures that have long existed in corporations and organizations to work in their partnerships."‚Å£
‚Å£
This may feel 'unsexy' but the upside to this system is that everyone knows where they stand and what their responsibilities are.  No one person is on the hook to assign jobs or keep tabs. ‚Å£
‚Å£
In the work I do as a @fairplaylife couples coach, I help couples adopt systems that work for them to more fairly distribute the work and the mental load of parenting and managing a home.  It can alleviate so much resentment and conflict. ‚Å£
‚Å£
If something like this might help your relationship, reach out to arrange a free call to learn more.

Israel at war: Two perspectives on the conflict in Gaza.‚Å†
‚Å†
As news of the war in the Middle East dominates headlines, it is easy to feel lost in one-sided narratives. For this week‚Äôs episode of "Informed," we provide you with two different perspectives on the conflict.‚Å†
‚Å†
Our first story comes from Marc Champion for @Bloomberg, who argues that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's response plan to Hamas attacks is valid. However, he emphasises the need for a new cabinet to execute it effectively. He reflects on the importance of Netanyahu's imperative to follow his advice to prevent a broader war and safeguard his legacy in a complex regional landscape.‚Å†
‚Å†
Our second story is from Stephen M. Walt for @foreignpolicymag, who contends that Israel‚Äôs pursuit of victory in the Gaza battle won‚Äôt contribute to resolving the longstanding issues of injustice and vengeance in the region.‚Å†
‚Å†
Head to our link in the bio to listen to both perspectives now.‚Å†
‚Å†
Listening time: 22 minutes.

I‚Äôve not read a work of rigorous investigative journalism that combines fervent advocacy as ùóî ùóóùóÆùòÜ ùó∂ùóª ùòÅùóµùó≤ ùóüùó∂ùó≥ùó≤ ùóºùó≥ ùóîùóØùó≤ùó± ùó¶ùóÆùóπùóÆùó∫ùóÆ. It‚Äôs a departure from the investigative journalism of Patrick Radden Keefe (‚ÄúEmpire of Pain‚Äù) in that I initially grappled with the question of whether advocacy is an inherent function of journalism or if it should present the facts and let readers decide for themselves. It would seem that when the facts are self-evident, advocacy is their logical cousin.‚Å£
‚Å£
As a long-time Jerusalem resident, Thrall provides a unique perspective and gripping account of the tragic bus accident that claimed the lives of Abed's son, Milad, and his classmates, when their bus collided with a trailer and erupted in flames. He delves into the experiences of Abed and the other parents as they searched for their children in the aftermath.‚Å£
‚Å£
In an interview with TIME, Thrall makes a direct link between these experiences and the system of controls Palestinians endure, which he describes as ‚Äúgrossly unjust‚Äù:‚Å£
‚Å£
‚ÄúThere's an elaborate system of color coded IDs that dictate who can go where even within the same family. There's a wall that snakes through and circles a community, ‚Ä¶ All of that is the everyday reality of all of these people, and they faced it on the worst day of their lives.‚Äù‚Å£
‚Å£
I purchased the book, prior to the Hamas attack, based on recommendations from The New York Times and The New Yorker. Investigative journalism has always been a favored genre, and as a mother of sons, the theme of conflict rooted in the loss of a child struck a chord. ‚Å£
‚Å£
‚Å£Also, I've observed the Middle East conflict's ebbs and escalations, and the fraught negotiations for peace, followed by the assassinations of leaders like Anwar Sadat and Itzhak Rabin. ‚Å£
‚Å£
A line from Thrall‚Äôs interview that reverberates is his assertion that in the conflict, "every American citizen is complicit."‚Å£
‚Å£
The conflict, now, war, has created within me what Adam Grant aptly describes as ‚Äúempathetic distress‚Äù. Regardless of whose ‚Äúside‚Äù you are on, perhaps you are experiencing this, too? ‚Å£

*Thrall > Krall

üìç Some prominent Republicans are distancing themselves from former President Donald Trump, after the current GOP frontrunner repeatedly criticized Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and offered unexpected praise for Hezbollah militants.

‚ÄúHamas, Hezbollah, Iran, the greatest state sponsor of terrorism, these are states and entities that are focused on wiping Israel off the face of the earth. That is neither smart nor good,‚Äù Rep. Mike Lawler (R-N.Y.), who represents a district that voted for President Joe Biden by double digits, told NBC News‚Äô Kristen Welker on Thursday. ‚ÄúThis is a fight of good versus evil.‚Äú

In an interview with Fox News‚Äô Neil Cavuto on Thursday, Rep. Mike Turner (R-Ohio), chair of the House Intelligence Committee, said that ‚ÄúDonald Trump has to answer for Donald Trump‚Äôs comment,‚Äù before adding that ‚Äúweakness begets conflict. Where people see an opportunity, where they‚Äôre looking at ways to harm others, where they don‚Äôt see a strong United States, they see opportunity.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôll never forget that Bibi Netanyahu let us down,‚Äù Trump said. ‚ÄúThat was a very terrible thing.‚Äù

Trump went on to say that he had ‚Äúa bad experience with Israel as president,‚Äù when his administration carried out a targeted airstrike in January 2020 to kill the Iranian general Qasem Soleimani, leader of the paramilitary Quds Force, who was in Baghdad at the time. According to Trump, Netanyahu refused to help the U.S. carry out the airstrikes.

In his speech, Trump also described the actions of the militant group Hezbollah ‚Äî an Iranian-backed proxy group based in Lebanon that the U.S. and other governments have designated a terrorist group ‚Äî as ‚Äúvery smart.‚Äù

Many of Trump‚Äôs GOP rivals have condemned his remarks, calling them ‚Äúinhumane‚Äù and ‚Äúabsurd.‚Äù The White House called the comments ‚Äúdangerous and unhinged‚Äù in a statement on Thursday.

Source: Politico
